That is one of the greatest opportunities for her to start reaching for her goals.

Iluminada C. comes from Antipolo, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is a 43-year-old woman, married, and is the mother of four children. For her age, Iluminada is seen as strong and determined to improve their quality of life.

loans.use: To pay for a renewal of city plate registration and purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her tricycle & jeepney

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en:
Nasiba, a 39-year-old internally displaced person from the region of Nagorno-Karabaka, currently lives in the Absheron region. A single mother of a 14-year-old boy, for the past eight years she has worked as a women's hair stylist, a job she likes very much because of the creativity involved and the way she makes her clients feel. Nasiba says it’s a good job for a woman with little education. Additionally, she works in the library of the local school during the early hours of the day and sells custom-made hair clips to the women in her neighborhood.

Currently, Nasiba’s workspace is small (4 sq. meters). Although her current income sustains her and her son, it does not generate enough income to buy more than very basic necessities. She’d like to use her loan of 2000 AZN to expand her business to attract more clients, hire an employee so that she can spend more time with her son, and be able to send him to university when the time comes.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
Ma. Elena O. is a 41-year-old married woman from Antipolo, Rizal. She and her husband are blessed to have three children. She is a member of the Upper Buhanginan center in Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) Rizal West Branch. She is a very strong-minded woman, and she remarks that she works hard to better her status in life. 

Despite hardships brought about by poverty, Ma. Elena remains strong and dedicated in her pursuit to improve her family’s standard of living. The love and support of her husband makes her life quite significant. To make a living, she operates a sari-sari (variety) store. She has been engaged in this business for more than seven years. 

She joined ASHI, a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2006. During the course of her membership, she has been an excellent performer with respect to her credit rating (basis of loans). She is now seeking her tenth loan, this time in the amount of 45,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory of groceries for her store. She is positive that, with access to additional working capital through ASHI and Kiva, her dreams of winning business and sending her children to a university so that they can complete their college degrees will be achieved. Her wish to give her children a good future is what drives her each day.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory of groceries

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 24 years old and married, and she has two children. She completed primary school. 

She is a tailor. She will use this loan to purchase a big sewing machine, cloth, and other sewing supplies. 

Because she is an experienced and skilled woman, many clients visit her and have her sew their garments. She has a good reputation in the market and that has earned her more clients who bring their sewing to her. She has an ambitious plan to develop her business and to get more income for her family.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and cloth

loans.name: Hrachya

texts.en:
Hrachya T. is a 36-year-old man, married with a newborn child. His mother and sister live with the family.  Hrachya is the main breadwinner in the family.

Hrachya used to sell vegetable oil, various food sauces and some food preserves. When the business stopped due to the economic crisis, Hrachya rented out a small bakery with a “tonir” (traditional Armenian wooden stove) where he cooks Armenian bread. Hrachya’s neighborhood loves the bread and would like to buy the fresh bread directly from him. Hrachya has requested a loan to buy another oven and open a small bread shop next to the bakery.

loans.use: Buy an oven and open a bread shop

loans.name: Kukirizakwe Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Like a giant refreshed, this 40-year-old woman is a personification of hard work and vigor. N. Jalia has, for the last seven years, given a worthy account of herself in a male-dominated business – to wit: a secondhand shoe enterprise – in Lugazi.

Like many other Ugandan women seeking to scrape out their own way to make ends meet, Jalia knew she had to go with the contemporary tide to guarantee for herself and her seven children a safe, sound and secure future. Prior to obtaining this footing in her current business, she was a milk-seller. She used the proceeds from her milk-sales business to start up this secondhand shoe business, with the help of a loan.

With a steady profit inflow, principally the 60,000 shillings she makes in a week, Jalia has managed to educate all her children. With this loan, her sense of optimism is sky-high, especially knowing that she will be able to purchase more shoes to sell. This, in the long run, will mean her profits will also increase.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand shoes to sell

loans.name: Jackielyn

texts.en:
Jackielyn D., 28, is from the village of Christine, District 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Jackielyn owns and operates a business venture in the food sector operating a retail and wholesale of "chicharon" (deep- fried pork rinds). While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling crispy fried pork rind in the local community. 

Jackielyn has been engaged in her business for over one year. She also has a direct selling business for almost three years. Both these businesses earn her around 6,000 PHP a month. She hopes that Kiva lenders will continue to support her throughout her fourth loan cycle.

In 2008, Jackielyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jackielyn is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Jackielyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Xa

texts.en:
Xa T. H. was born in 1951. She lives in Luong Quy village, in the Dong Anh district. To earn a living, she not only grows rice but also raises pigs. Her husband is retired and earns a monthly income of approximately 1,500,000 VND. Mrs Xa, meanwhile, also has a monthly income of approximately 1,500,000 VND.

She explains that she has been a member of SEDA since 2008 and has a proven track record of promptly repaying her loans. In this loan cycle, she is seeking to borrow 6,322,000 VND ($350) to purchase food for her pigs.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing food for her pigs

loans.name: Nemengo Womens Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
27-year-old N. Fatuma has come a long way in her retail shop business. It has now been four years of hard toiling and constant planning to stay ahead and above her competition.

This married mother of three is full of optimism and it’s one of the factors that has contributed to her elevation. Fatuma is a young woman with every quality to succeed and this can manifestly be shown in the 250,000 shillings she makes in a month.

Fatuma also sells new clothes in her shop and this gives her extra income. She has made sure that all her children are in school. With this loan, she wants to revitalize her business by buying more retail items for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items like soap and sugar

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mr. Heng S. is 47 years old and lives in the province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, which is about 200 km from Phnom Penh along National Road No. 6. He and his wife have three teenage children who are no longer in school and who are currently working.

Heng S. earns a living by cultivating crops on his own land in the village. He normally sells the crops to buyers when the crops are sufficiently ripe. His wife typically stays at home to do housework, but she also works with him to assist him with the business. Because crop-growing and -selling is the primary source of income for his family, Heng S. is requesting a loan in the amount of $375 in order to buy fertilizers and vegetable seeds to grow additional crops.

loans.use: To improve his business by purchasing fertilizers and vegetable seeds

loans.name: Sevindj

texts.en: Sevindj A., a 38-year-old single mother with two daughters, lives in Baku city where she has been selling personal products for five years. Her shop is 15 sq. meters, and she buys her goods at discount prices at Bine Trade Centre.  Although her current income sustains her and her daughters, it is not enough to buy more than basic necessities. With her loan of 2000 AZN, Sevindj would like to buy more merchandise and eventually expand her business and hire an employee so that she can spend more time with her children.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Kiduusu Women's Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
She goes by the name of N. Sarah, a 30-year-old evergreen entrepreneurial upstart, being that she is only five years into her bar business in Kiduusu, Lugazi. With this business she has given all her five children a worthwhile education as she works hand in hand with her husband.

Casting her mind back in perspective to when she was still a farmer, Sarah says she has no nostalgic feelings or regrets as her financial position since then has tremendously gotten a boost. Though only still a fledgling, her bar business has given her that leverage and flexibility which she, at the threshold, did not envisage.

Sarah also ekes out profits selling bananas and vegetables that she buys from farmers. By and large, she reveals she makes monthly profits to the tune of 140,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to inject more capital into her business with a set objective of making more profits. Principally she wants to buy more crates of beer and soda for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer and soda for her bar

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Mrs. Kun K. is 41 years old. She has a life partner in her husband, who buys used goods in bulk and then re-sells the goods for a profit. By doing so, her husband earns approximate $3.50 per day. She and her husband are the loving parents of a young child, who is enrolled in school.

To earn a living, Kun K. cultivates local crops, including rice and potatoes. She also collects and sells the mature/ripe crops, which is normally three or four months after planting the seeds. In order to expand her business and to improve her family’s income (and standard of living), Kun K. is now requesting a loan in the amount of $375 from Kiva’s project partner, HKL, to grow additional potatoes.

loans.use: To expand her business by planting additional crops

loans.name: Bujuuta B Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
B. Gorreti is a cheerful 44-year-old married mother of four lively school children. She runs a five-year-old salon business in Bujuuta, Lugazi. She offers hairdressing services and also sells cosmetics to her ever-increasing clientele.

Gorreti left her farming business to start up her current business. With monthly profits of 300,000 shillings, she casts her mind to the future with optimism. Her sense of determination is an attribute she says is invaluable in this kind of business.

With this loan, Gorreti wants to buy more cosmetics and also hairdryers for improved services.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics and hairdryers for her salon

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma E., 51, is from the village of Rang-Ayan. She is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Norma owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Norma has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns around 3,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Norma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Norma is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Norma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Herman

texts.en:
He is a happily married 50-year-old man still diligently giving a good, hard-work account of himself in his policing work. While many individuals at that age are thinking about slowing down and retirement, he is not about to rest on his laurels.

K. Herman has been a police officer for the last fifteen years in Mpigi. His good track record in the line of police duty has won him accolades and homage from his superiors.

On a paltry monthly salary of 150,000 shillings, Herman has gone to every length to give his family that lease of welfare that they need in the course of every passing year. All his eight children are happily in worthwhile schools around Mpigi Town, notwithstanding his modest salary.

Herman wants to use this loan to buy a plot of land where he, at length, intends to build rental apartments to increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land for future rental apartments

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites M., 47, is from the village of San Rafael. She is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Marites has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns around 5,200 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Marites is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marites from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina G., 35, is from the village of Bitag Pequeño, Baggao, Cagayan. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Gina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns around 3,000 PHP whenever she sells her raised animal.

In 2009, Gina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Gina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Maksim

texts.en: Maksim is 40 years old and an internally displaced person from the region of Khalbadjar. He now lives in the Absheron region. He is the sole provider for his family and has two teenage boys. In his store he sells cooking pots and dishes, a business he learned from his brother 10 years ago. Maksim is asking for a loan of 2000 AZN to update his merchandise. He hopes that having more (and newer) merchandise in his store will help him sell them more competitively. To buy new items, he’d travel to the Logbatan region.

loans.use: to update his merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 28 years old and married. He finished intermediate school. 

He is a blacksmith. He will use this loan to purchase a new iron welding machine, iron bars and other necessary materials for his business He will benefit significantly from this loan and he will be able to develop his business. He has a good character and has earned a fine reputation among his friends in the market. In addition, he is very skilled and has nice designs and good ideas. Many clients order windows and doors for their new houses from him, because he charges a reasonable price compared to the other shops.

loans.use: To develop blacksmith shop

loans.name: Bulenga Twekembe, Mpigi Group

texts.en:
This maternity business in Bulenga has been 49-year-old K. May’s main source of livelihood for the last twenty-eight years. Prior to this, she bore a hand in a small boutique business.

To make her future business prospects doubly sure, May has gone out of her way to show good client handling skills. This has enormously played into her favor as manifested by an increase in her profits over the course of the years she has been operating. In a week’s period, her business has been generating her on average 100,000 shillings.

May’s future reckoning is to be able to buy more furniture and consignments of drugs for her maternity business. With this loan, she sees this coming to fruition.

loans.use: To purchase new furniture and drugs for her maternity business

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora M. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 48 and married with one school-aged child. Leonora has a business selling ice cream to the local community. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Leonora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product line. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Leonora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product line

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia C. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 52 and married with four school-aged children.  Lilia runs a general store selling a variety of different products. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product line. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Lilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product line

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 28 years old and married, and he has two children. He passed primary school. 

He owns a food store. He will use this loan to purchase a vertical refrigerator and food. He has a good reputation in the market and among his friends. He sells good-quality food at reasonable prices, so many customers buy their daily necessities from him. His business is the main source of his family income.

loans.use: To purchase a vertical refrigerator and food

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita P. is from the village of Centro 2. She is 49 and married with eight school-aged children.  Merlita has a tailoring business providing general  alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Merlita has been engaged in her business for over 32 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Merlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase a transport vehicle for her business. Merlita is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Merlita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her childrens' tuition fees. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth R. is the loving and self-sacrificing mother of six children. She appears young and strong in her older years. The desire that Elizabeth harbors in her heart is to increase her capital to invest so as to acquire more inventory for her sari-sari (variety) store. Additional capital will allow her to create more revenue to support her her family. Above all, she hopes to provide a better quality of life for her beloved children, all of whom need her support. 

Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 30,000 PHP. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for five sacks of rice and to purchase an inventory of groceries for her store. Let’s get together behind this devoted mother to help her keep bring well-being and security to the members of her family. Elizabeth believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, as well as providing for the education of her six children. She is very grateful to ASHI and Kiva for their support of her dreams. As a loyal member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2005, Elizabeth is thankful for secured access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams. She hopes to diversify her revenue in the long term to support the basic needs of her family.

The support of ASHI and Kiva lenders will enable her to have a growing business, invest in her home, improve her life, and have a happy family.

loans.use: To buy five sacks of rice and to purchase an inventory of groceries for her store.

loans.name: Hana

texts.en:
Hana A. Haikal is a hard-working woman from Hebron City in Palestine. After getting a divorce, Hana established her own beauty salon in order to take care of her only son and her ill mother who lives with her and to cover life expenses. The salon was very primitive, but she started taking loans from FATEN to develop it.

The salon offers all beauty services, such as hair cuts, nail polish, and hair dying. Hana came to FATEN and took a $2,000 loan to purchase wedding gowns that she rents to brides who come to her salon for make-up and hair-dos.

Hana's son has entered a beauty school so he can help his mother by working in the salon. In the photo, she is showing the gowns that she purchased.

loans.use: Purchase wedding gowns

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta E. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 46 and married with school-aged children. She runs a general store selling a variety of different products. Marietta has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4200 PHP a month.

In 2008, Marietta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marietta is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product line. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Marietta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product line

loans.name: San

texts.en: San N. is 45 years old and has been selling fresh fish in the busy local market for more than nine years. The fish she sells are either caught by her husband, Phang Nang, 42, or she buys them from her wholesale supplier and from other fishermen. Her husband fishes in and around the lakes of his community. Currently, San N. needs to pay the fee for hiring a taxi to deliver the fish to the market for selling. She desires to cut down this fee by looking for a loan to purchase a second-hand motorcycle, so that she can travel without hiring a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand motorcycle in order to transport fish to market for sale

loans.name: Chaka

texts.fr:
Âgé de 38 ans, Monsieur Chaka est mariée à deux épouses, père de 7 enfants et vit chez lui-même avec sa famille dans le quartier Darsalam I de la préfecture de Koutiala   (Région de Sikasso).  
Dû à des problèmes de famille, il n’a pas pu continuer  les études raisons pour laquelle il s’est vite accroché aux activités génératrices de revenus  depuis son jeune âge, auprès de son frère. Il y a 15 ans que Chaka s’est spécialisé dans l’achat vente de motos Djakarta et ses pièces détachées.  Cette activité lui est très rentable et  lui procure assez de revenus car il reçoit beaucoup de commandes dans le mois.  
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle et l’élargissement de son activité,  Monsieur Chaka a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle, il est à son deuxième  prêt individuel, après avoir remboursé sans aucune difficulté le premier.  
Ce prêt servira à acquérir une quantité importante de pièces détachées de moto Djakarta  pour la vente.  Il s’approvisionne  au grand marché de Koutiala et effectue sa vente dans la ville  de Koutiala à une clientèle composée de femmes et  d’hommes, au comptant ou a crédit.  
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Chaka compte réaliser un  bénéfice de 110 000 FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts, prendre en charge les besoins de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité. 
Il envisage rembourser ce prêt correctement pour qu’il puisse bénéficier un autre dans le but d’élargir son activité.
texts.en:
Monsieur Chaka, 38, is married to two wives, the father of seven children, and lives in his own house with his family in the Darsalam I neighborhood of the prefecture of Koutiala (Sikasso Region). Because of family problems, he was not able to continue in school, for which reason he quickly began to earn his living, at a young age, working with his brother. 15 years ago, Chaka began specializing in Djakarta motorcycles and their spare parts. This business is quite lucrative and brings in enough income, since he receives a good number of orders each month. In order to satisfy the needs of his clientele and expand his business, Mr. Chaka came to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his second individual loan, having correctly reimbursed the first. This loan will allow him to acquire a lot of spare parts for Djakarta motorcycles. He buys his supplies in the big open-air market of Koutiala and sells his goods in the town of Koutiala to a clientele composed of women and men, for cash or credit. With this loan, Mr. Chaka expects to make a profit of 110,000 F CFA per month which he will use to reimburse the interest, cover family expenses, and invest any remainder back into his business. He intends to reimburse this loan correctly so that he will be able to get another, with a view to expanding his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of spare parts for resale

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma G. is 38 years old and lives in the province of Rizal in the Philippines with her husband and four young children.  To supply additional income for her family, Vilma has opened a food vending business in her neighborhood.

She has enjoyed profits from her food vending business, and so she has been able to sustain the needs of her four children and improve their lives. With that, Vilma is encouraged to work harder and aim further for her business, partly using the loans she can access to support her business. Therefore, Vilma wants to take this opportunity to grow her business by requesting for another loan of 15,000 PHP from our Kiva lenders for an additional business capital. She wants to buy a larger volume of supplies for her food vending business so as to attract more clients and secure the loyalty of her regular customers.

Her long term goals are to have a successful food vending business, help fund the college education of her siblings, and support her family financially.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she is determined to achieve business success with her new entrepreneurial endeavor. Vilma’s desire to give her children a brighter future fuels her dedication to her business.

loans.use: To buy a larger volume of supplies for her food vending business

loans.name: Ma. Luna

texts.en: Ma. Luna B. is 28 years old and makes a living by by fishing. Like mothers everywhere, nothing brings her as much joy as seeing her two children happy and provided for. That is why she and her husband work so hard, and what has motivated them to establish their small business. Ma. Luna has applied for a loan through ASHI to expand her business by buying a motor boat to use for fishing. Her husband will run the boat, and she will sell their catch to people in their village.

loans.use: To purchase a motor boat for fishing

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian L. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 36 and married with three small children. She provides a manicure and pedicure service in the local community and has been engaged in her business for over 16 years earning approximately 2500 PHP a month.

In 2007, Vivian joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Vivian is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services she provides. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Vivian from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This entrepreneur is 40 years old and married. She is a seamstress. She will use this loan to purchase an embroidery machine and cloth. She has been doing domestic sewing for more than 10 years. She’s a skilled woman in this area of business. All of her neighbors ask her to sew their clothes. The price of her sewing is reasonable, so many clients wish to go to her. She possesses a high reputation in the district. She is planing to develop her business in the future. With the the income from her business, she can help her husband with the family's living expenses.

loans.use: To buy an embroidery machine and cloth

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam Al A. is a single woman from Deir el Balah in the Gaza Strip. Mariam is 35 years old and lives with her parents. Two years ago, her father had to retire due to illness, so Mariam decided to start her own business to cover the family's expenses. 

Mariam rented a small shop and started a supermarket in the neighborhood where she lives. The supermarket is doing very well, due to Mariam's good manners and neighbors who are willing to help her by buying from her small store.

Mariam came to FATEN and took a $1,000 loan to purchase additional goods. This will attract more customers and result in more returns.

In the photograph, Mariam stands in her store.

loans.use: Purchase goods for a supermarket

loans.name: Alimata

texts.fr:
Madame Alimata  B. est âgée de 28 ans, mariée  mère de 3  enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame avec son mari, sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans le quartier Koulikoro  de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Enseignante de profession, elle exerce parallèlement, des activités génératrices de revenus, notamment la teinture et la vente des habits depuis maintenant 7 ans.  Elle est très bien connue dans ce secteur,  car elle teint et vend des bazins teintés de qualité.  
Pour une bonne  satisfaction de sa clientèle en quantité et en qualité, elle décida de s’approcher de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel et le prêt précédent a été correctement  remboursé.  
Avec ce deuxième prêt Madame Alimata B. compte acheter deux pièces de bazin riche, 3  kg de potasse et des colorants pour la teinture. 
Elle s’approvisionne dans la capitale du  Mali (Bamako) et effectue sa vente dans les différents structures professionnelles et quartiers de la ville de Koutiala à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes à crédit et au comptant très généralement .  
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 100.000FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage utiliser pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et prendre une partie des dépenses scolaires de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Alimata B., 28, is married and the mother of three children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her co-spouse, and their children in the Koulikoro neighborhood of the prefecture of Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). A teacher by training, she also has been earning money dyeing and selling clothing for the past seven years. She is well-known in this sector, since she dyes and sells high-quality "bazin" (damask cloth), In order to satisfy the needs of her clientele as far as quality and quantity go, she decided to come to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she is on her second individual loan, the first one having been correctly reimbursed. With this second loan, Mrs. Alimata B. intends to buy two lengths of high-quality "bazin", three kgs of potash, and dyes for her work. She buys her supplies in the capital of Mali (Bamako) and sells in various offices and neighborhoods of the town of Koutiala to a clientele composed of woman and men on credit but mostly for cash. She expects to make a profit of 100,000 F CFA per month which she intends to use to reimburse the interest on the loan and pay a part of her children's school fees.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "bazin" and dyes

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice P. makes a living by selling maize flour and onions at a local market, and is applying for a loan to buy additional items, such as tomatoes and dried fish, to sell. Alice is 30 years old and married to a teacher. She has two children, one of whom goes to school.  With the extra income made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to build a house. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena C. is from the village of Bitag Pequeño, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 37 years old. Rowena is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Rowena owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products in the local community. Rowena is just starting this business.

In 2009, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rowena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support members of her immediate family.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kassipin

texts.fr:
Madame Kassipin Traoré est âgée de 48 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants, elle vit dans une famille polygame dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). 
Madame Kassipin n’a pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école c’est pour cela qu’elle s’est très vite intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman. Après biens d’années d’apprentissage, elle s’est spécialisée dans la fabrication de savons traditionnels et l’exerce pour elle-même depuis maintenant plus de 20 ans. 
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle en quantité et en qualité, Madame Kassipin n’a pas pris du temps pour faire  recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  depuis 3 ans.  Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous remboursés correctement, elle  est à son troisième  prêt  individuel dont les deux précédents ont été bien remboursés.  
Ce nouveau prêt servira à acquérir, 5 barriques de déchet d’huile alimentaire pour la fabrication du savon à Koutiala. Elle  effectue sa vente dans les différents quartiers de Koutiala à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle espère sur un bénéfice mensuel de 85 000 FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts, participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kassipin Traoré is 48 years old, married and the mother of five children. She lives in a polygamous family in the Hamdallaye district of the Koutiala Prefecture (Sikasso Region). Mrs. Traoré did not have an opportunity to go to school, and this is why she had started learning trade skills from her mother from an early age on. After many years of training, she decided to specialize in the preparation of traditional homemade soaps, which she has been doing on her own for over 20 years now. In order to meet her customers’ expectations as to both quantity and quality, Kassipin lost no time in getting in touch with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, which she joined 3 years ago. After four solidarity (group) loans, all duly repaid, she is now on her third individual loan. The previous individual loans have also been properly repaid. This loan will allow her to purchase in Koutiala five barrels of cooking oil waste needed to make soap. She sells her wares in different quarters of Koutiala to a customer base composed of women and men, for cash and on credit. She hopes to achieve a monthly income of 85,000 West African Francs, which she will use to repay the interest on her loan, contribute to the everyday family expenses and reinvest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing food oil waste

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 26 years old and single. He is student in an evening high school. In addition to his studies, he has a blacksmith shop. He will use this loan to develop his shop, to purchase an iron welding machine, and to make some shelves to hold the iron bars. 

He has good reputation in the market and he is a dependable guy. He has a strong desire and ambition to raise his income. He has been in this business for 5 years and he has a great deal of experience in his field.

loans.use: To buy a welding machine and shelves for iron bars

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
Lily K. makes a living by selling tea and bread in a restaurant, and has applied for this loan to buy new supplies of sugar and milk. Lily is 28 years old and married to an electrician. She has one child who does not yet go to school. With the extra income made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy additional supplies of sugar and milk

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia A. is from the village of Bitag Pequeño, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 47 years old. Sonia is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Sonia owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sonia has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sonia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Sonia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her offering of products. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Sonia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Pann

texts.en: Mr. Pann S. is a 51 years old, married and father to three children. He makes a living by buying bran in bulk from people who have a grinding machine and then sells it to retail customers. In additional to this business, he has built a stall next to his house where he raises a pigs to generate extra income. He wife stays home to do housework and help to fatten the pig. This couple's children all attend the local school. Mr. Sophia owns a piece of land on which he would like to grow rice. He has applied for a loan to hire a laborer to plow this land.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to plow his land

loans.name: Sanata

texts.fr:
Madame Sanata D. est âgée de  56 ans, mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle vit avec  son mari et ses enfants  dans le quartier Hamdallaye  de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).  
Madame  Sanata n’a pas fréquenté l’école, elle fut victime de l’époque où les filles n’avaient pas la possibilité d’aller à l’école, alors  elle s’intéressa à l’activité génératrice de revenus que sa mère menait à savoir la transformation des noix de néré en Sounbala.  Elle exerce cette activité pour elle-même depuis maintenant 30 ans. 
Au Mali, le Sounbala est l’un des condiments alimentaires le plus important et très prisé par les femmes et vu la qualité  de ses productions, cette activité lui procure assez de bénéfices car elle peut vendre plus de 5 gros paniers dans la semaine.  
Pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, Madame Sanata a sollicité la collaboration de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans. Après  8 prêts solidaires et deux prêts individuels, tous  remboursés  correctement, elle est à son 3e  prêt  individuel qu’elle  compte utiliser pour acheter, 10 sacs de noix de néré  auprès des commerçant spécialisés dans le stockage de céréales de Koutiala. Elle vend à Bamako et à Kati  à une clientèle composée essentiellement   de femmes,  au comptant.  
Sanata compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 85.000FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le  remboursement des taux d’intérêts de Soro et contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sanata D. is 56 years old, married and the mother of 6 children. She lives with her husband and children in the Hardallaye neighborhood in the city of Koutiala, the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. Mrs. D. did not attend school. She fell victim of that period when girls did not have the opportunity to attend school. She was taught by her mothe, becoming interested in eaning income by transforming nere seeds into Sounbala, a local West African spice. She has been practicing this business for thirty years. In Mali sounbala is one of the more important basic food condiments and well prized by women. Because of the high quality of her production, this business grown to a point where she sells more than 5 large baskets of product each week. To increase her operating capital, Mrs Sanata has been collaborating with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance group for five years. After duly repaying 8 group and 2 personal loans, she plans to use her 3rd personal loan to buy; 10 sacs of nere nuts from the specilized cereal sellers in Koutiala. She sells to a clientele made up predominantly of women for cash, in the cities of Barnako and Kati. Sanata expects to earn a monthly income of 85,000 francs CFA, which she plans to use to repay her loan to Soro Yiriwaso and contribute to improving her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies of nere nuts

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion G. is from the village of Centro 2. She is 46 years old. Concepcion is married and has five infant children. To make a living, Concepcion owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Concepcion has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Concepcion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Concepcion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Concepcion is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Concepcion from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: In

texts.en: Mrs. In P. is 55 years old, married and the mother of eight children. Four of her children are married and live away from home, while other four still live at home  and help the family by earning income at various jobs. Mrs. P. and her husband work as farmers, growing green beans and potatoes. After harvest, she sells her crop and plans a new one. Mrs. P. is applying for a loan to expand her farming business by planting a new crop.

loans.use: To expand her business by planting a new crop.

loans.name: Aclia

texts.en:
Aclia J. is currently in the business of selling clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes and bed sheets to sell.  Aclia is 41 years old and is married to a businessman. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a permanent shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more clothes and bedsheets to sell

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou G., age 40, is from the village of Rang-Ayan. She and her husband have three school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou runs a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Marilou joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Marilou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marilou is now requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items, with the goal of expanding her store's product offering. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Marilou from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items in order to expand her store's product offering

loans.name: Muong

texts.en: Muong I. is an older woman, 69 years old, and a resident of the rural area of Phnom Penh, where she has owned a plot of land since 1979. She grows rice crops, which she plants twice a year. She is a widow and the good mother of eight children. Two are single and six are married and live away from home. To help meet her family's expenses, one of her daughter's is working in the garment factory. Muong I. will be using her first loan to buy more tools for her farming operations.

loans.use: To buy more tools for her farming operations.

loans.name: Alilo

texts.en:
Alilo A. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Alilo is 42 years old and married to a farmer. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Emelder

texts.en:
Emelder P. is currently in the business of selling both dried fish and fresh ones at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and onions to sell.  Emelder is 44 years old and is married to a businessman. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Djavanshir

texts.en:
Djavanshir is 63 years old. He has two sons and two daughters. His wife, Banovsha, is pictured above and works with him in their shop. They are internally displaced persons from the region of Fuzuli, and they now live in the Absheron region. 
In their shop, Djavanshir and Banovsha sell things needed for weddings. They have been in this business for 17 years. In traditional weddings, the bride must bring towels, tablecloths, curtains, bedding and other things for the couple’s home. Djavanshir and Banovsha are requesting a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy more merchandise. Summer is a very popular season for weddings and they hope to have many orders. Many people prefer their products because they sell quality and inexpensive items.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Enayat

texts.en:
Enayat K. is a married woman from Gaza City in Gaza Strip. She is 28 years old and has 3 sons and one daughter. Enayat's husband, Ziyad, is an employee of the Palestinian National Authority. His salary barely covers their household expenses, so Enayat started another business to help her husband afford the expenses of their large family.

Enayat and her husband rented a small store and started a mini-market where she sells the basics to people in the neighborhood. To increase the benefits of her business, Enayat came to FATEN to take a $2,000 loan to purchase goods. Enayat works in the mini-market as does her husband when he comes back from his work in the evenings.

Ziyad appears in the picture in front of the goods they sell in the mini-market because his wife is conservative.

loans.use: Purchase Goods

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en: C. is a 30-year-old married man and father. He works as a military policeman and earns a suitable salary to help control all his family’s financial problems. He has a life partner in his wife who appears in the photo here. She is a good homemaker who cooks tasty meals for the family and also farms a rice crop. This couple has been married for years, but they don’t have any children. After the rainfall, C. is looking for a loan for his wife to plant rice.

loans.use: To plant rice.

loans.name: Asenta

texts.en:
Asenta K. is currently in the business of washing and ironing customers' clothes at the laundry shop and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of washing powder and boxes of soap.  Asenta is 31 years old and is widowed.  She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a dry cleaning machine.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of washing powder and boxes of soap

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita A. is currently in the business of selling beer and local brew at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Tita is 40 years old and a widow.  She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bar.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem R., 45, lives in Kompong Tom Province where she has had a medium-sized plot of farmland since she was single. She grows rice and has two crops per year, in both the dry and rainy seasons. To find additional income, she built a pigpen behind her house where she raises hogs and sells them when they mature. Sem R. is married and has four teenage kids. Two of them are no longer in school and work. Her husband, Ro, 44, distills rice wine to earn a living. Also, he makes natural medicine and sells it to patients who live nearby his village. Sem R. is taking out her loan to accumulate more pigs for her stall. Any remaining cash from the loan, she will buy raw materials for her husband use to produce medicine.

loans.use: To obtain more pigs for her stall.

loans.name: Prospere

texts.fr:
Femme âgée de quarante deux ans,celibataire avec quatre enfants dont l'âge varie de 20 ans à dix huit mois.Elle s'est lancée dans la petite patisserie (vente des beignets et riz au lait) depuis plus de 10 ans.
Cette activité lui permet de faire vivre sa famille et de prendre en charge la scolarité de ses enfants. Chaque matin,elle se lève tôt, s'installe au coin de la rue,située non loin d'une école et du marche du quartier  pour commencer la préparation et la vente de ses beignets et riz au lait pour satisfaire ses potentiels clients qui ne sont autres que les enfants de l'école primaire,les vendeurs du marché et les passants.
Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter 150 kg de farine,50kg du sucre, 50l d'huile,du bois de chauffe;50k de lait,50kg de riz et une grosse marmite. Pour la croissance de son affaire elle fait preuve d'une bonne gestion et ameliore la qualité des produits qu'elle presente à ses clients
femme gentille,courageuse et très accueillante à su susciter l'interêt de son quartier. Dans l'avenir elle veut entreprendre une autre activité pour agrandir son commerce et faire plus de bénéfices et pense aussi à ameliorer ses conditions de vies ainsi que celle de ses enfants.
texts.en:
This lady, 42 and single, with four children whose ages range from 20 years to 18 months old, has been selling cooked food (fritters and milk rice) for more than 10 years. This business allows her to support her family and pay school fees for her children. Every morning she gets up early, settles down on a street corner, not far from a school and the neighborhood market, and begins preparing and selling her fritters and milk rice to satisfy her potential customers who are none other than the primary school children, merchants from the market, and passers-by. With this loan she intends to buy 150 kg of flour, 50 liters of oil, firewood, 50 kg of milk, 50 kg of rice, and a big pot. In order to grow her business, she has demonstrated good management and is improving the quality of the wares she offers her customers. She is a kind, courageous, and very welcoming woman who has aroused interest in her neighborhood. In the future she is planning to undertake another business to make more sales and more profit, all with the intention of improving living conditions for herself and her children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy supplies wholesale for selling fritters and milk rice

loans.name: Rawiya

texts.en:
Rawiya J. is a 36-year-old mother of two sons and one daughter. Rawiya's husband, Omar, is an employee of the Palestinian National Authority. Five years ago, Rawiya and Omar started a small computer shop in Gaza City. Omar worked in a computer maintenance shop during college, so they decided to open a computer maintenance shop.

Rawiya came to FATEN and took a $3,000 loan to purchase computer accessories, which will increase their benefits and bring in more customers. Rawiya manages the shop during the day, receiving customers, handing out fixed computers, selling accessories, and managing financial issues. Omar works in the shop in the afternoons.

In the photograph, Omar stands in the shop, because Rawiya doesn't want her picture published.

loans.use: Purchase computer hardware

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok S. has been in the farming business for years. She plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of over $3 per day. She is married, but her husband died of senility years ago. She has five children, all of whom are now married and live independently. Sok S. lacks money to buy a piece of farmland on which she plans to plant crops for additional income. Sok S. is therefore applying for a $300 loan to buy land.

loans.use: To buy a piece of farmland.

loans.name: Barikama Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Barikama sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 44 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le quartier Bagadadji de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des relations de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le marché de Bagadadji. 
Elles font le commerce de spaghetti,  de riz, de savons, de pagnes wax et brodés. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce et de faire leurs achats au comptant, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles  sont à leur 3ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Kadia D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 300 cartons de savons de marque Sama (Éléphant) contenant chacun 12 morceaux. 
Elle se ravitaille en savon avec les fabricants de Bamako qui font des produits de très bonne qualité d’après elle-même. Elle les revend en détail au comptant et à crédit à domicile, au marché de Bagadadji parfois et en ambulant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame Kadia D. à l’instar des autres femmes du groupe espère avoir un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour épargner et prendre en charge les petits besoins de la famille en condiments. 
Elles ont pour ambition d’ouvrir des magasins de vente de leurs marchandises dans leur quartier dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The five women of the Barikama group are married and mostly live in monogamous families. They are on average 44 years old, with four children and live in the Bagadadji quarter of Ségou (the fourth largest administrative region in Mali), and met through neighbours and their revenue-generating businesses in the Bagadadji market. They sell spaghetti, rice, soap, wax cloths and embroideries. In order to increase their business funds and to purchase goods by cash, the group members have called upon Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their third loan. Madame Kadia D. aims to use this loan to purchase 300 boxes of Sama (Éléphant) soap, each containing 12 bars. She replenishes her soap stock through Bamako suppliers who, in her opinion, make good quality soap. She sells these for cash and credit through home sales, sometimes at the Bagadadji market and sometimes door-to-door sales, to a customer base of men and women. Madame Kadia D., like the other women in the group, hopes to generate an average monthly profit of 35000 FCFA which she would save and use to meet her family's modest needs. The women would like to open stores in order to sell their wares in their local quarter, thanks to a partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase soap

loans.name: Tat

texts.en: Mrs. Tat T., 36, is a local rice trader in the village. She always buys rice in bulk at reasonable price from farmers. She also saves up many kg of rice before selling out for a profit. By doing this job, Tat T. is able to generate formal proceeds to help feed her five kids. All five of the children are attending the public local school. Also, she relies on the income from her husband’s business. He fishes in and around Tunle Sap Lake. Tat T. will use the loan she has requested to purchase piglets for a pigpen she built. With any remaining money from the loan, she will order rice to resell.

loans.use: To purchase piglets.

loans.name: Rasmiya

texts.en:
Rasmiya is the mother of one son and one daughter. She is a 43-year-old woman from Gaza City in the Gaza Strip. Her husband is an employee of the Palestinian National Authority.

Two years ago, Rasmiya opened a small clothing store in the city where she sells children's clothes. The store has many customers and the number increases over time. Since the summer has arrived, Rasmiya bought a large supply of clothes to sell. Therefore, she came to FATEN and took a $3,000 in order to pay off 3 months of her rent in advance. 

Rasmiya stands next to the beautiful children's dresses in her shop.

loans.use: Pay off rent

loans.name: Huot

texts.en: Mrs. Huot S. is 37 years of age and a resident of Siem Reap Province. To generate a daily income, Huot S. is a local laborer who is hired by people to harvest their mature crops. Additionally, she also goes with her husband to fish in and around the river. This couple has given birth to six children who are public school students. Because their current income is not adequate to serve them, Huot S. is looking for capital to invest in a pig raising business. Mrs. Huot S. and her mother are pictured above.

loans.use: To invest in a pig raising business.

loans.name: Esther B.

texts.en:
Pictured above is Esther B. K. on the left and loan officer Mary Conteh on the right. Esther is a teacher at the MCA Primary school in Alkalia village, which is about 25 miles away from Kabala town in northern Sierra Leone. Esther has applied for a loan of SLL 1,000,000 from SMT/Kiva lenders.  

Esther and many other teachers apply for loans from SMT. With the help of these loans, they can buy or do something big that their mere salaries could not buy or do. Esther wants this loan of SLL 1,000,000 in order to pay college fees for her child. 

Forty-two-year-old Esther was born in a place call Yiffin, near Kabala town. She is married to a laboratory technician and the couple has one son who is currently at university.

loans.use: Pay college fees for her son

loans.name: Bertin

texts.fr:
Homme celibataire de 38ans ayant deux enfants dont l'âge varie entre 12 et 10 ans.Il exerce son activité depuis 1996et avait commencé avec un capital de dix mille Francs CFA,il est vendeur des friperies(sandales et sacs)au marché Total à Bacongo, qui est le plus grand marché de Brazzaville.
Il va utiliser ce prêt pour l'achat des grands stoks de sandales et sacs.popur la croissance de son activité il est toujours à la recherche des produit de la dernière mode au prix bas ensuite il fait des livraison et vente au domicile de certain client en dehors de son étalage du marché.
ses ambitions s'est d'aller à l'étranger pour s'approvisionner afin d'être grossiste. IL veut aussi que ses enfants fassent des grandes études et qu'ils bénéficient d'un héritage.
il est parmi les premiers client de HOPE CONGO qui amene même ses compétiteurs pour profiter du prêt. IL est très ouvert et gentil avec son entourage et contribue à l'épanouissement de ses voisins.
texts.en:
This gentleman is single, 38, with two children 12 and 10 years of age. He has been in business since 1996 and began with 10,000 F CFA in working capital. He is a salesman of used items such as sandals and bags at the Total market in Bacongo, the biggest open-air market in Brazzaville. He intends to use this loan to buy lots of sandals and bags to grow his business. He is always on the lookout for stylish products at low prices which he then delivers for sale to the homes of certain of his customers, above and beyond his display at the market. His ambition is to go overseas to buy supplies so that he can be a wholesaler. He also wants his children to attend higher education and have an inheritance. He is among the first clients of HOPE CONGO and he brings even his competitors in to take advantage of receiving a loan. He is very open and pleasant with those around him and contributes to the well-being of his neighbors.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: wholesaling  of bags and sandals

loans.name: Entesar

texts.en:
Entesar T. is a 41-year-old woman from Gaza City in the Gaza Strip. She is married to Mazen T. and is the mother of two daughters and two sons. Mazen used to own a poultry shop where he prepared poultry for sale. He is now an employee of the Palestinian National Authority.

Entesar decided to restore their poultry shop and urged her husband to start working there again in the afternoons. Entesar came to FATEN and took a $2,000 loan to purchase a machine that cleans the poultry automatically. Entesar believes that this machine will make the work faster and increase the number of customers they can serve.

Mazen appears in the picture working in the shop because his wife is not comfortable having her picture published and he is the one who works in the shop.

loans.use: Poultry sales

loans.name: Emmanuel M.'s Group

texts.en:
In the photo above are members of the D.E.C Central Senior Primary School and loan officer Mary Conteh on the left. District Education Committee (D.E.C) Primary school was founded in 1915 in Kabala town, northern Sierra Leone. It is a government-assisted school with about 30 government-paid teachers and a few community-paid teachers. The school has a population of 1,250 pupils. 

The leader of this group of teachers is Emmanuel M. M.. The 35-year-old is married to a petty-businesswoman and the couple has two children. Emmanuel, who was born in Bafodia village, near Kabala town, has been teaching for six years now. With his share of this loan (SLL 700,000), Emmanuel will use part to pay school fees for his two school going children and part for his wife to invest in her business.

(Attached to the photo are some snapshots of borrowers who were not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children and invest in his wife's business

loans.name: Edward M.s.'s Group

texts.en:
In the photo above are members of the R.C. Primary School Junior. These are diligent and hard working teachers who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 11,400,000 in order to help them pay school fees for their children, invest in a business, buy pieces of furniture, or buy a plot of land, etc. R.C Primary school was founded in 1954 in Kabala town. It is a government-assisted school with 13 teachers, twelve of whom have applied for a loan of SLL 11,400,000.

With the help of this loan, the leader of this group, Edward M.S. M. will use his share (SLL 1,000,000) to purchase house equipment/furniture. Edward is a 54-year-old man who is married to a petty businesswoman. They have three children. 

(Attached at the sides of the photo are some snapshots of borrowers who were not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To buy house equipment/furniture

loans.name: Firyal

texts.en:
Firyal is the mother of four sons and two daughters. She is married and lives in Gaza city in Gaza Strip.
