Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy more products to sell.

location.town: R.J. Macias, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome T. is from the village of Bularan Miputak. She is 45 years old. Salome is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Salome owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Salome has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Salome joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Salome has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. Salome is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her "carenderia" (small restaurant) business. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Salome from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional capital for her carenderia business

loans.name: Choum

texts.en: Mr. Choum B. is a 39-year-old married man. He has a school-aged child who depends on him. He lives with other family members in his own small family home in Siem Reap province. Choum B. owns a piece of land that he inherited from his parents. He grows different kinds of crops on his land, such as green beans and potatoes. He sells his crops to buyers every two or three months when the plants mature. In addition, Choum B. and his wife take time to fish around the river for additional profit. As he hopes for a good result in this cultivation season, Choum B. is applying for assistance from Kiva to grow green bean crops.

loans.use: To grow green bean crops.

loans.name: Renabel

texts.en:
Renabel A., age 33, is from the village of Rang-Ayan. She and her husband have one school-aged child. To make a living, Renabel runs a general store, selling a variety of different products in  her local community. Renabel has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Renabel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and to increase her ability to engage in business activities. Renabel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Renabel is now requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Renabel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
Consuelo V. is from the village of Holy Friday. She is 44 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Consuelo owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Consuelo has been involved in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP whenever she sells her raised animal.

In 2009, Consuelo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Consuelo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Consuelo is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the third loan taken out by Consuelo from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Michaela

texts.en:
Michaela P., is from the village of Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Michaela is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Michaela owns and operates a buy & sell business. Michaela has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Michaela joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Michaela is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Michaela from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Joseline

texts.en:
Joseline Pate¤o is from the village of Tipan. She is 30 years old. Joseline is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Joseline owns & operates a business venture selling bamboo products in the local community, specifically Sun Breaker. Joseline has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Joseline joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Joseline has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Joseline is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 11th loan taken out by Joseline from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mr. Sok T. is a 43-year-old laborer. He is also hired by people to do anything, especially construction jobs, typically earning about $3 USD per day. Sok T. currently feeds a young child, while another one is now married and lives independently. He has a life partner in his wife who appears in the photo here. She farms a rice crop and is also a good homemaker who cooks delicious foods. Due to the coming farming season, he will plant his crop in good weather. As he hopes for a good result, Mr. Sok T. requests a loan of $200 in order to buy farming tools for the purpose of growing crops.

loans.use: To buy farming tools.

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sitha C. (shown in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Deth Sam, live on an Island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1980 and have two daughters. Both daughters are married, but one lives outside the family home.

Mrs. Sitha C. has been selling vegetables and pork in front of her house for more than two years. Besides this business, she also supplements her income with new silk weavings to earn extra income to support her family. Her husband has been a house builder for more than five years.  

Sitha is asking for her second loan of $300 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her daughter’s weaving business.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey M. and her husband, Mr. Pet Port, have been married since 1978. They have seven children: three sons and four daughters. Three of their children are married and live in separate homes, one works in a garment factory, one is a construction worker, and the other two attend school. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River. 

Mrs. Srey M. has been a silk weaver since she was twenty years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then sells them in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a farmer. She is requesting a loan of $100 to repair the motorcycle for her son.

loans.use: To repair the motorbike for her son.

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita L. is a 68-year old married woman who lives in San Francisco, Santa Catalina, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by engaging in a fishing business.

Florita’s 40 year old husband, Lowim, owns and manages his own bakery business. They have 3 adult children. 

Florita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a fishing business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP20,000 from her business activities.

Florita is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP19,000 was used to fund the operations of her fishing business, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 18th cycle loan, the amount of PHP19,000, which she intends to use on her fishing business. Florita is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal T., is 37 years old and her husband, Mr. Yeun Sri (pictured together), is 41, live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1993 and have three children - two sons and one daughter. All of them are still young. 

Sophal and her husband are farmers. They grow vegetables on their farmland in the village. The couple does not have enough capital to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides to maintain their vegetable farm. So, Sophal is requesting a loan of $1,000 to help her capital.

loans.use: To use for farming.

loans.name: Carreon's Group

texts.en:
Evelyn C. is from the village of Pob. Manukan. She is 37 years old. Evelyn is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is C.'s Group.

Evelyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Evelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional capital for her sari-sari store. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Evelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional capital for her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mr. Mon T. is highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He receives a lot of orders from his clients to construct their houses. He has a partner in his wife, who appears in the picture above. She owns a medium farmland next to her house, where she cultivates rice crops. This couple has two children; both are students and live in the family home. Presently, Mon T. doesn’t have electricity system and he has been planning to connect it for a long time. Due to the fact that electricity connection requires a service fee, Mr. Mon T. has decided to seek a loan to be used to pay for connecting a new electricity line for the family's use.

loans.use: To pay for connecting a new electricity line.

loans.name: Srun

texts.en:
Mrs. Srun C. (shown in the photo) and her husband, Mr. That Khorn, have been married since 1995. They have three children: one son and two daughters. One of her daughters is in grade seven and other two stay at home. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River. 

Srun has been a silk weaver for twenty years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a farmer, he grows rice and vegetables. In addition, he wants to run a new battery charging business. He will be able to get extra income from the new business as well. 

Hence Srun is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a generator to for her husband to launch the business.

loans.use: To purchase a generator to for her husband’s battery charging business.

loans.name: Nema

texts.en:
Nema G. is a 41-year old married woman who lives in Calumpang, Barangay Mabini, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living with her general store business.

Nema’s 43 year old husband, Enrique, is a farmer, and they have 3 children. Two of the children are adult aged while the other child is currently going to school and also helps the parents in the business as part of daily chores.

Nema joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP10,000 from her business activities.

Nema is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP10,000 was used to fund operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 10th cycle loan, the amount of PHP13,000, which she intends to use on her general store business. Nema is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna P. (shown in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Vang Pang, have been married since 1992. They have four sons. All of them are in school. The family lives along National Road number Two, about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh City. 

P. sells fish in the village that her husband catches. Besides fishing, the couple also grows peanuts and lotus. P. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase fishing materials for her husband’s fishing business and she will use a part of her loan to rent more plots of the land to grow lotus.

loans.use: To purchase fishing materials for her husband’s fishing business and to rent more plots of the land to grow lotus.

loans.name: But

texts.en: Mrs. S., age 56, is a widowed mother who has four children, three of whom are married and one is single and works sewing clothes in the garment industry. She is a domestic rice cultivator who owns piece of farmland. She has operated this sector, since 2000. She also buys rice in bulk at a reasonable cost, to resell to gain income. S. has been using her own farming machine to plow the land. Recently, the machine has broken some spare parts so the plowing process has been suspended for a while. Because of this problem, Mrs. S. has applied for a loan to purchase parts to renovate the broken part of her old machine.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to repair the broken farming machine.

loans.name: Sokleang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokleang T. (pictured here), 43 years old, and her husband, Mr. Piseth Huy, 53, live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1993 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. The eldest daughter is a garment factory worker and other three attend school. 

Sokleang is a farmer. She grows bananas and flowers. Her husband is an electrician. She does not have enough capital to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides to maintain her banana and flowers farm. So, she is requesting a loan of $1,000 to help her capital.

loans.use: To use for farming.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie A. is a 43 year old widow who supports her family by engaging in raising ducks for sale and selling eggs. She lives in Prk Calumpang, Barangay Mabini, Valladolid, Negros Occidental with her 4 adult children.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her raising of ducks for sale and selling of eggs, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP10,000.

Tessie is now borrowing PHP20,000 so that she can continue to raise ducks and eggs for sale. This will be her 14th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP20,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Tessie aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Sreymao

texts.en:
Sreymao is single and lives with her parents and brothers and sisters along National Road Number One, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She has been a farmer for more than twenty years. She grows vegetables and flowers and sells her products to a middleman. 

Sreymao previously asked for a Kiva loan to purchase a motorcycle for commuting one time already. But, she changed the purpose of the loan to connect her house to an electricity utility service, because she did not have electricity to use especially at night.
Now she is applying for her second loan of $800 to continue the purpose of purchasing a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mr. Seng U., 45 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sida Kao (both shown in the photo), 38 years old, have been married since 1988. They have five children: three sons and two daughters. One is married and lives outside the family home, one is a garment factory worker, two attend school and another one is still young. They are living along national road number one, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Seng and his wife are farmers. They grow rice and vegetables on their farmland in the village. But, the couple does not have enough capital to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides to maintain their rice and vegetable farm and to pay for plowing fees.  

Hence Seng is asking for his first of $1,200 to help his capital.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his rice and vegetable farm and to pay for plowing fees.

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Mrs. Soy Y. (pictured with her son), is a widow with four sons. One of her sons is married and lives in a separate home, another one is employed full time, and the other two are in school. The family lives about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Soy has been selling groceries for more than twelve years. She buys groceries from the market for resale at her home. She previously asked for a Kiva loan to buy more groceries for her inventory once already. Now, she is asking for her second loan of $600 to continue expanding her business.

loans.use: To continue expanding her business.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom C. (shown in the photo), 60, and her husband Mr. Say Nut, 58, have been married since 1969. They have eight children: four sons and four daughters. Five of the children are married and live outside the family home, two weave silk at home and another one assists his father in the business. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. The couple is old, but they are still strong enough to work. 
Mom has been a silk weaver for thirty years, while her husband has been a wooden house constructor for three years. He works in the nearby district and other provinces. Mom is asking for a loan in the amount of $1,200 to purchase silk materials for her and her daughters’ weaving business and to buy additional construction materials for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and buy additional construction materials for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophea T. (pictured with her young son), 45, and her husband, Mr. Vun Torn, 46, have been married since 1986. They have six children: one son and five daughters. One weaves silk at home, three attend school, one stays at home and the last is very young. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River. 

Sophea has been a silk weaver since she was seventeen years old.  She learned the skill from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a farmer that grows rice and vegetables. Besides the farming business, Sophea and her husband raise a horse and a cow.  She is applying for a loan of $1,000 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business and build a shelter for the animals.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and build a shelter for her animals.

loans.name: Irenea

texts.en:
Irenea Z., 51, is an active member of ASHI. Her two children, ages 19 and 21, are the inner force that pushes her to work harder each day and increase her income through a small business. She receives financial support for her business from ASHI loans. In 1997, she opened a small variety store with a loan.  At the time, she only sold a few items. Despite the small scale, Irenea has been able to make a small profit from her store. Making a profit from her store allowed her to augment her husband's income from working as an electrician. Their combined income enabled her to support the needs of her two children, especially their education.

Over the years, Irenea’s business has grown a bit through the support of loans received from ASHI. Using the proceeds of her business she was able to finance her eldest child to attend college.  Irenea is supporting the needs of her children, especially those of the 19 year old, who only finished high school. Irenea never gets tired of supporting her family because it keeps her alive. She wants to increase her store's profit by expanding her variety store into a huge grocery store.  This would allow her to support the education of her youngest child if he considers going back to school and attending college.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her variety store.

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun Y. (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Phy Phat, have been married for more than thirty years. They have four children. Three of them are married and live outside of the family home and the fourth weaves silk at home. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Saroeun has been a silk weaver since she was young. It’s a skill she learned from her parents. She also started a new business selling finished silk fabric. She buys them from the weavers in the village and transport them to sell in other districts. Saroeun does not have enough capital to operate the business. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of $350 to support her business.

loans.use: To purchase finished silk fabric for resale.

loans.name: Munkhjargal

texts.en:
Munkhjargal is 30 years old and lives with her husband and 3 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own small and old house. Her 10 year old daughter and 7 year old son attend a local secondary school. Her younger son is 1 years old and attends local kindergarten. Her husband works in a company. 

Munkhjargal operates a clothing business out of a rented stall at a local market. Once a month, Munkhjargal gets new products from Beijing. Because she only buys high-quality products and receives them from Beijing, the clothes she offers are usually better than those offered by the other sellers. Munkhjaigal is a very hardworking person and likes to say “Nothing is impossible”. Her goal is to eventually have enough money to embark upon her real dream job: opening her own shop. Recently, in 2009, Munkhjargal and her husband purchased a new car. She is requesting a loan to build a new and big house

loans.use: to build a house.

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarorn U. (pictured here), age 42, is widow with two sons and one daughter. One of her children is married, another one is a garment factory worker and the youngest one attends school. The family lives about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sarorn has been raising pigs and producing rice wine for a year. She is asking for her first loan, in the amount of $1,200, to use for raising pigs and to purchase a motorbike and trailer to transport rice wine to sell.

loans.use: To use for raising pigs and to purchase a motorbike and trailer to transport rice wine to sell.

loans.name: Enkhtuya

texts.en:
Enkhtuya is 49 years old and lives with her husband and 2 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her 2 sons, Soyol-Erdene and Munhzorig attend University. 

Enkhtuya operates a taxi service in her town. She enjoys transporting people. She says, “I must be very responsible and careful when driving my car in order to provide a safe ride for my customers.” Enkhtuya started her business in 2007 after she sold her own house. During that time she gained much experience in conducting a business. Enkhtuya is very hard working and is known for her good character. She has gained a lot of experience over the years and is a trusted driver for her many customers. She works hard to maintain her success and is hopeful about the future. Her family is the most important thing for her and she says, “As a mother, I would like to be financially available to provide a good education and other necessary expenses for my children until they graduate from University. I would also like to expand my business. She is requesting a loan to build a house on her own land.

loans.use: to build a house.

loans.name: Tuk's Group
loans.use: To mend and decorate her old house.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Mrs. Kim M., is 46 years old and her husband, Mr. Vorng Horn (pictured together), is 51 years old. They have been married for since 1981. They have six children: three sons and three daughters. Three of them married, one is a construction worker, one is assists her mother in the business and the youngest attends school. The family lives in a small village off of National Road number Two about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Kim has been a farmer for two years, she grows vegetables on her farmland in the village and sells her vegetables in Takhmao market, about 4 kilometers from her house. Her husband is a fisherman and construction worker.  

Kim is applying for her first loan of US$1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting and carrying vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting and carrying vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda P. is a 52-year-old married woman who lives in Prk Luna, Brgy Mabini, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by keeping a vegetable plantation and selling the products.

Glenda’s 57-year-old husband, Danilo, is a farmer, and they have 4 children who are adults while the others are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Glenda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 40,000 from her business activities.

Glenda is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund operations of her vegetable plantation, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 15th cycle loan, in the amount of Php 20,000, which she intends to use on her vegetable plantation and in selling the products. Glenda is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Working capital for her vegetable plantation

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en: Otgonbayar is a humble, helpful and open-minded person. She lives with her husband and two sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They all live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Otgonbayar currently operates a transportation business in the city using a van she owns. Every day she makes six trips between two transportation terminals in the city. She collects fares and announces stops as her driver drives. Her husband works as a driver at a local company. Her oldest son, Munkhzul, is 15 years old and attends high school. His 6-year-old son, Munkh-Erdene, attends kindergarten. While she enjoys the work, her voice is starting to tire after years of loudly announcing route stops. Otgonbayar started her business in 2005, after obtaining a loan to purchase her van. She recently had to purchase a bus as the city government plans to enact a law forbidding the use of vans for transportation in the city. She says that "my family's living conditions have improved a lot since I started running transportation." She is requesting a loan to purchase a built house.

loans.use: To buy a built house

loans.name: Sokmali

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokmali C., aged 37 (pictured here) and her husband, Mr. Soktry Khut, aged 37, live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1999 and have two sons and one daughter. All of them are in school. Besides of her children, she also has her elderly mother living with her.     
 
Sokmali has been a tailor since 1993. She operates the business out of her home. Her husband is a security guard. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to fill up the land in front of her house and add an addition to her house.

loans.use: To fill up the land in front of her house and add an addition to her house.

loans.name: Un

texts.en: Un C. is an older mother living in Siem Reap Province. She has seven children, one of whom is married and the remaining six are single. Some of them can earn money to help meet with family's living expenses. Since 2000, Un C. has run a business selling fish at the market. She sells fish that she buys from her supplier and is currently earning an average of $6 per day. She always receives help from her husband to sell the fish. Because selling  fish is the main way for her to earn money, Un C. is applying for a loan to accrue the amount of capital from her fish business.

loans.use: To accrue the amount of capital from her fish business.

loans.name: Thou

texts.en: Thou K. is 45 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than nine years. She sells fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing, or buys them from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. She is married to Setha, 42, who works as a fisherman in and around the lakes of his community. Currently, the fishing is temporarily interrupted because his fishing equipment is broken. For this reason Thou K. requested a loan in order to buy additional fishing equipment.

loans.use: To buy additional fishing equipment.

loans.name: Ochirmunkh

texts.en: Ochirmunkh is 58 years old and lives with his wife and two children. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His 21-year-old daughter graduated from university, and now she's helping the family’s business. His younger son is 12 years old and attends a local secondary school. In 2009, Ochirmunkh started selling bricks to local construction companies. From the beginning, the business has been doing well, with business capital increasing from 300,000 MNT (about $217) to 2.5 million MNT (about $1,800). Ochirmunkh dreams of owning a larger brick factory that can meet the needs of larger construction companies. He also hopes his son will achieve a high level of education. His family is the most important thing for him and he says, “as a father, I would like to be financially available to provide a good education and other necessary expenses for my children, and also I would like to expand my business and to purchase my own apartment or house for my family in the future." Ochirmunkh is now requesting a loan to purchase business equipment such as a brick machine.

loans.use: To increase working capital.

loans.name: Chea's Group

texts.en: This is a group loan that contains four members. Mrs. S. is the group leader. Mrs. S., 50, is a fish catcher. Normally, she goes to the middle of the river where she always fishes. She hurries to bring the fish to the market after she finishes fishing. Her husband owns a boat that he uses to provide a delivery service for a fee. With their incomes, Mrs. S. always manages her cash carefully. She cares for five children, while another two are now married. Mrs. S. is taking out her loan to purchase more tools for her fishing activity. The other borrowers are Mrs. S., a fish catcher asking for a loan to purchase a machine to attach to her existing boat for fishing, Mrs. K., who earns an income by fishing and is requesting a loan to repair her old house, and Mrs. S. O., who also catches and sells fish. Mrs. O. is applying for a loan to purchase planks for the propose of building a new house. They are all people who are living in the province of Siem Reap, in Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase more tools.

loans.name: Erdenebat

texts.en: Erdenebat is 36 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live together in their own house. His daugther, Munkhchuluun, is 14 years old and attends a local secondary school. His younger daughter, Munkhchimeg, is three years old and attends kindergarten. During the day, Erdenebat’s wife, Tsogzol, operates a trading business at a local market called Narantuul. She operates a retail business and purchases a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border city, and resells them for a profit. She started her business in 2000 with working capital of 500,000 tugrugs ( about $362). After years of successful operations, she has managed to increase her working capital to a level exceeding 2,000,000 tugrugs (about $1,445) today. Erdenebat operates a transportation business in his local area. Erdenebat is now requesting a loan for his wife's business to purchase a variety of products in Ereen, a Chinese border town, to resell for a profit.

loans.use: To increase working capital.

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
As they say, determination leads to destiny, and M. Fred is gaining momentum in his charcoal-selling business. Many people tend to undermine casual work but the 57-year-old married father of two children and two dependents has been able to earn a living through that business for twelve years.

Charcoal is commonly used here in Uganda as a form of energy in many homes that cannot purchase paraffin (kerosene), gas or electricity. Through the selling of charcoal Fred is able to earn 250,000 Ugandan shillings monthly as profits, though having drawbacks like transporting his products to bigger markets such as Kampala city.

With this loan, Fred hopes to expand into bigger markets. He says that he inherited his business from his father after his father’s death and works hard to ensure that he expands it further.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell to expand his business

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda B. is from the village of Vira. She is 45 years old, widowed and has 2 school-aged children. Imelda owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Imelda has been involved in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2006, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia M. is from the village of Holy Friday. She is 52 years old, married and has 4 adult-aged children. Delia owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Delia has been involved in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Delia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Delia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Delia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites G. is from the village of Holy Friday. She is 44 years old. Marites is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business hauling plastics & other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase used bottles and newspapers to sell. Marites is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional waste & junk material to sell. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Marites from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional waste & junk material to sell

loans.name: Petra

texts.en:
Petra C. is from the village of Marabulig 1, Cauayan City,Isabela. She is 50 years old. Petra is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Petra raises livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Petra has been engaged in her business for more than 20 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her raised animals.

In 2009, Petra joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Petra is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP, which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Petra from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira S. P. is from the village of Marabulig 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 51 years old. Elvira is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Elvira sells home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling door mats, pillow cases, and bedding supplies in the local community. Elvira has been engaged in her business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Elvira joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elvira is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Elvira from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bwambara Women's Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
Very hardworking T. Jovia has been operating a produce sales business from Rushaya in Rukungiri for a period of thirteen years.

With nostalgia, this happily married mother of six children recalls how her business basked in high profits at its outset. Times have changed, however, as the business now is showing diminishing returns, earning her 120,000 Ugandan shillings monthly on average. This is in sharp contrast to the 250,000 shillings she says she was making at the start of her business.

There is always a story connected with people in western Uganda who, despite laboring under such tough times, find a way of educating their children. Jovia is no exceptional to this. What she is looking forward to now is the prospect of enhancing her business by buying more maize, beans, rice, millet, cassava, and other crops with the help of this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Kahengye Adult Development Group

texts.en:
A determined and very hardworking B. Richard, aged 32 years, is the married father of two children and three helpless dependents. He has operated a retail shop business for four years selling general merchandise in Kahengye, Rukungiri.

At the end of every month Richard is able to pocket profits to the tune of 180,000 Ugandan shillings in addition to his monthly salary for his teaching profession. He employs one person to help with his shop while he is away. His main drawback has been having a small amount of stock in business that cannot match the consumption rate of the customers.

Richard is therefore seeking a loan that he figures will help him stock more goods that will satisfy his customers’ high demand and also transform his enterprise into a wholesale business. Being very committed to the business, with good customer care, he hopes to increase his sales revenue. This will bring about a transformation in his business and enable him to achieve a self-sustaining life and cater for his family’s requirements.

loans.use: To buy more stock for his retail shop

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana F. is from the village of Olango. She is 48 years old. Juliana is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Juliana raises livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Juliana has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 3000 PHP when she sells one of her raised animals.

In 2008, Juliana joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Juliana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Juliana is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Juliana from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Serina

texts.en:
Serina C. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old. Serina is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Serina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Serina has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Serina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Serina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used towards additional capital for her business. Serina is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Serina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma C. is from the village of Marabulig 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 57 years old, married and has five adult children. To make a living, Thelma owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling door mats and bedding supplies to local community members. Thelma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Thelma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This  will be the eighth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Rwabigangura Bakyara Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
If you subsist on agriculture, as N. Juliet has found out, you need enormous reserves of patience to succeed. That particular attribute has manifestly worked in Juliet’s favor. She speaks with pride of how her four children can all attain an education in institutions of learning.

Juliet’s proficiency in attending to her banana plantation for the last twenty years in Karuhembe, Rukungiri, has bore her fruits of economic development. In a month, she makes profits to the tune of 300,000 Ugandan shillings. The only major drawn-out problem that has plagued her business has been the persistent low banana market prices in villages and the fact that she has no ready means of transporting her produce to bigger markets.

It’s Juliet’s reckoning that this loan will come in handy in helping her enhance her banana plantation on a large scale through mulching and the buying of fertilizer, the profits of which will help with taking care of her family. She says that, in addition to the banana plantation, she also grows coffee, maize and beans.

loans.use: To buy mulches, fertilizer and farm tools for her banana plantation

loans.name: Chuo's Group

texts.en: There are four borrowers in this small group, all residents in the province of Siem Reap, Cambodia. Mrs. T. was selected to be the leader. She owns a medium-sized boat that she and her husband use to provide a taxi service. T. picks up merchandise belonging to people across the river and currently earns an income of approximately $8 per day. She is married and has two young children; both of them are single. Mrs. T. is facing an obstacle: the roof of her boat cracked during the heavy rainfall, and this problem has been affecting her service and daily income. Therefore, T. decided to request a loan to renovate the broken roof of her boat. The other three borrowers are Yon S., 44, and Kean T., 39, who sell groceries, and Seat N., 63, a barber. Ms. S. needs a loan to buy more grocery inventory for sale. Ms. T. also needs a loan to accumulate the quantity of grocery inventory to sell, and Ms. N. is applying for a loan to help her finish building a new house.

loans.use: To renovate the broken roof of her boat.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda E. is from the village of Marabulig 1. She is 45 years old, married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns and operates a specialized store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling beverages such as soft drinks and juices in the local community. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand the product range. This will be the fourth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the product range

loans.name: Nakiggudde Twekulakulanye Group, Mpigi

texts.en:
Ever since he took the reins in his retail business in Nakiggudde, Mpigi, he has worked relentlessly hard, year in, year out, with the sole objective of making profitable and worthwhile use of his time. As such, 28-year-old K. Joseph has made a lot of financial headway. It’s now a decade and he is still breaking new ground in the elevation of his business.

Joseph’s longevity in this business has enabled him to gain solid experience that he reckons improves his chances at easily making the best out of any inevitably hard situations that may manifest themselves in the future. As a result of his sense of determination, this married father of five cheerful and boisterous children has significantly improved his family’s status quo. 100,000 shillings is what accrues to his business in a weekly timeframe.

To go with the tide that other business people have an inclination for, Joseph also runs a farming business that enables him to eke out side-profits. Under the auspices of this loan, he envisages being empowered to bring about rejuvenation measures. He principally wants to buy more general retail merchandise for his shop. He is looking at buying sugar, salt and crops like maize and beans to sell.

loans.use: To purchase retail items like sugar, salt and crops like maize and beans for his shop

loans.name: Xuraman

texts.en:
Xuraman, a 42-year-old single mother of two daughters, 12 and 16 years old, lives in Baku city where, for the past 10 years, she has been selling woman’s clothes in her small store. Xuraman buys the clothes in Lokbatan, a shopping center where items are sold at low cost, and unlike most of the retail stores in Baku, she sells clothes for bigger-sized women. Because of this, her shop has many loyal customers.

Xuraman is now seeking a loan of 2000 AZN to expand her store. She’d like to buy more clothes to sell and hopes that with additional income, she will be able to hire another employee so that she can spend more time with her children.

loans.use: To expand her store

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en:
Cristita A. is 62 years old, married, and lives in the province of Rizal in the Philippines with her husband and four children. To provide additional profits for her family, Cristita is opening a local sari-sari (variety) store in her neighborhood.

Cristita would like to receive a loan to purchase inventory including 10 sacks of rice, sugar, five sacks of charcoal, and inventory of other foodstuff for her store. Cristita believes in offering a relevant variety and inventory of goods in her store for customers looking for convenient purchases, and to attract more customers in local community. As a good member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Cristita is thankful for the access to capital and loans to fund her entrepreneurial dreams.

Her long term goals are to develop her retail business, finance the college education of her four children, and support her family morally and financially.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she is determined to win more business with her new entrepreneurial effort.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her variety store.

loans.name: Shakhla

texts.en:
Shakhla, 45, lives in Baku city with her husband and three children, ages 10, 12 and 15. All five members of her family share a room in a communal apartment. Shakhla’s business is a store known as “1000 trivial things” in Azerbaijan because it sells everything that a person might use in daily life, from umbrellas and needles to screwdrivers. She has been working at this business for the past nine years.

Shakhla is now seeking a loan of 2000 AZN to buy new merchandise for her shop. As you can see from her picture, she doesn’t have much merchandise left as her husband's illness left them with little money to buy new things for the shop.

loans.use: To buy new merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Aygun

texts.en:
Agyun is 26 years old and lives in Baku with her mother and 13 year-old brother. She is not married. As her mother is sick and cannot work, Agyun is the sole provider for her family. Her job is selling shoes in a small store. She has been doing it for the past 5 years. Agyun is seeking a loan of 2000 AZN to buy wedding shoes and purses to resell in her shop, since summer in Azerbaijan is a popular season for weddings. 

In the future, Agyun hopes to design shoes of her own as she really enjoys drawing and designing different styles of shoes on paper.

loans.use: to buy wedding shoes and purses to resell

loans.name: Avazaga

texts.en:
Avazaga is 55 years old and an internally displaced person from the Fuzuli region. For the past 15 years he has lived in Baku with his wife and two sons, aged 15 and 20. Avazaga has been a dentist for the past 18 years. His father was also a dentist and Avazaga trained with him after he graduated from medical school. His oldest son is also studying dentistry. 

Avazaga is seeking a loan of 2000 AZN to by new dental tools because his current tools are outdated. He wants to make his clients happy with the quality of his work.

loans.use: to by new dental tools

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Amelia S. D. is hopeful that her sewing business will provide a steady income and improvements in her family’s quality of life. Her sewing business has grown and requires more capital to sustain it. Because of this, Amelia is requesting a loan through Kiva partner, ASHI, so that she can support the growth of her business and meet the increasing demands of her customers. Without capital, Amelia’s business will not grow and she will not be able to provide suitable services to her customers. Through the support of ASHI and Kiva, she hopes that someday her family's standard of living will change and they will be able to break away from the ties of poverty. She is grateful for access to capital and other services such as savings and insurance.
Amelia’s dream is for her only child to complete college. She also hopes to continue her sewing business as a sustainable livelihood to support her family and give employment to others in the community.

loans.use: To support the growth of her sewing business

loans.name: Nakalama C 1 East Mutesi Ayub Group

texts.en:
M. Ayub is a business lady, twenty-six years old, who is married with two children of whom one is schooling. She also cares for two dependents who are schooling.

Ayub has run a charcoal business for over five years. She is using the loan to purchase bags of charcoal to stock as much as she can for sale. She is an encouraging business lady whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal to stock as much as she can for sale

loans.name: Hok

texts.en:
Hok M. is a 38-year-old married woman and mother. She works sewing clothes for the garment industry and gets a salary of US$120 a month, providing her income to manage her family’s daily expenses. She is married with two young children who are enrolled in school. Her husband is Mr. Eum Nhor, age 31, and he works in the construction sector.

This is the second loan Hok M. has requested. She always faces difficulty with traveling needs because she doesn’t own a vehicle. Therefore, she is taking out this loan to buy a motorcycle to provide transportation for herself and her family.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for her family's transportation needs

loans.name: Pacencia

texts.en:
Pacencia B. joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) because she wanted to have her own business, since her husband's income is not enough to sustain the daily needs of their family. She and her husband aim to use Kiva loans to develop a stable business so they can support the daily needs of their family.

Pacencia would like to receive a loan to purchase inventory to continue her sewing business including cotton fabrics and other materials needed in her business. As a member of ASHI, a Kiva micro-finance partner in the Philippines, Pacencia is thankful for access to loans to support her dreams.

With the support of ASHI and Kiva, Pacencia is optimistic that her sewing business will produce a steady income to improve her economic stability and her family’s quality of life. Her longterm dreams are to continue supporting her children and grandchildren as well as to build a stronger home that can withstand flooding common in her province. She also dreams of owning a successful tailoring shop five years from now so that she can give employment to others in her village, specially her relatives.

loans.use: To pay for cotton fabrics and other materials needed in her sewing business

loans.name: Purevdavaa

texts.en:
Purevdavaa J. is 23 years old and lives with his father and sisters in his own apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family also own a small plot of land on which they plant vegetables.

Purevdavaa and his family built an apartment building for fifteen families which they rent to other families. The apartment building was completed four years ago and now needs general repairs, maintenance and redecorating. The family wishes to provide comfortable apartments to their renters at a low cost.

Purevdavaa is a clever, business-minded person. He says, “I am thinking of getting married and having children in the future.” He is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to repair apartments which he rents.

loans.use: To repair  apartments that he rents

loans.name: Theodomil

texts.en:
Theodomil is 28 years old and is still single. He lives by selling a variety of goods including cooking oil, drinks, cosmetics products, etc. He has been in this business for about six years and the hours of his business are from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Theodomil is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through adding a large quantity of foodstuffs such as different types of flour, Irish potatoes, rice, etc. With these additional goods for sale, he hopes that he will earn more profits than previously. Those profits will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business and build his own house which he has wished for for a long time.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of foodstuffs for his store

loans.name: Ronaldo

texts.en:
Ronaldo D. L. is from the village of Centro 2. He is 44 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Ronaldo owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle transport services. Ronaldo has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Ronaldo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. As with his previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI which was successfully repaid, the new loan of 3,000 PHP will be used to repair his existing vehicle to improve the service. This will be the seventh loan he has taken out from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair his vehicle to improve the service

loans.name: Dolgormaa

texts.en:
Dolgormaa M. is 51 years old and lives with her husband and two children in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Both of her children, aged 19 and 22, are students. Her husband, Jargalsaihan, works as a driver for a hotel.

Dolgormaa operates a milk-trading business in her district. She owns three cows which produce the milk and she sells it to a store with which she has a supply contract. She has only been operating her business for one year but hopes to purchase another cow in the near future to increase her output.

Dolgormaa is a hardworking person and focused on the future. She sees great potential in her business and says, “I must grow my business to save money so that I can support my children's school tuition fees.” Dolgormaa is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase another cow and calf for her business

loans.use: To purchase a cow and calf

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty A. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 49 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Betty owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling alcoholic beverages including beer and wine in the local community. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Betty joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Betty is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the fourth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita L. is from the village of Marabulig 1, Cauayan City. She is 46 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling door mats, pillow cases, aprons and bedding supplies to local community members. Anita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 6,200 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Anita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the sixth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nakalama C 1 South Isabirye Ibrahim Group

texts.en:
I. Ibrahim is a businesswoman, fifty years old, who is married with ten children of whom six are schooling. More so, she is looking after six dependents who are schooling, too.

Ibrahim runs a business selling used clothes and she has been in this business for over twenty years. She is using the loan to purchase more used clothes to sell such as skirts, dresses, T-shirts, trousers, and so forth.

Ibrahim is an encouraging businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Ardakbubu's Group

texts.en: Ardakbubu K. is the leader of this group. She is 52 and her husband works as a teacher of French language. They have two daughters and three sons. The daughters are married and live separately with their own families and the other children are students. Ardakbubu has been breeding cattle and cultivating fruits and vegetables since 1994 (in 1994 the collective farms broke up and people received some part of the land for farming). When her husband is free, he helps her with this activity. With money received from the loan, Ardakbubu wants to purchase 150 liters of fuel, which is needed for farming. In the future she plans to increase the number of her cattle to be able to pay for her sons' education. Zholdoshbek S. is 61 and is married. He has raised two sons and two daughters. All the children are married and live separately with their families. Zholdoshbek and his wife have been breeding cattle and farming for sixteen years. Now he wants to obtain a loan to purchase 150 liters of fuel, which is needed for the sowing process. Elmira A. is 43 and is married. She has three daughters and three sons. Two of her daughters study at university, two older sons go to school, and the other children are too young. Elmira and her husband have been breeding cattle and cultivating fruits and vegetables since 1994. Now Elmira has applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase fuel for farming. Meerim A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 23 and married with a two-year-old daughter. Meerim and her husband began to breed cattle and cultivate different fruits and vegetables four years ago. She wants to obtain a loan to purchase fuel for farming. In the future, she wants to increase the number of her cattle and improve her family’s living conditions. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
