Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fuel for the sowing process

loans.name: Fiend

texts.en:
Fiend is 40 years old and is still single. He owns a shop where he sells a variety of goods such as cosmetics goods and some other goods which are indicated by his photo. He has been in this business for about a year and his shop is open from the morning hours until late in the evening.

Fiend, after realizing that his capital is too low an amount to earn more profits, would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase his capital. With this increased capital, he hopes that his sales, as well as his profits, will increase and these profits will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods for his store such as cooking oil, sugar, rice, different types of flour, beans, peas, etc.

loans.name: Galiya

texts.en:
Galiya L. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her 7-year-old daughter currently attends a local primary school, and her husband works for the Water Piping Facility Board.

Galiya operates a vegetable business in the city. She has been engaging in this trade for sixteen years and has gained significant experience. She purchases her vegetables from wholesale traders and sells them from a rented stall as a retailer.

Galiya has been planning to expand her business in order to improve her family's quality of life. She is a hardworking and very energetic person. She says, “My dream is to finish my own house and live in it with my family.” She is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more vegetables for her business and will use the remaining part to complete construction of her home.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell and to complete construction of her home

loans.name: Romelia

texts.en:
Romelia F. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 46 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Romelia owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Romelia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,200 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Romelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Romelia is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand the product range. This will be the sixth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

She is using her loan to purchase more stock of used clothing for resale. Eva is a promising businesswoman whose dreams are to educate her children and obtain a plot of land.

Aristide needs to expand his shop by adding a variety of foodstuffs: mainly sugar, rice, beans, Irish potatoes, etc. These additional goods will hopefully allow him to earn more profits than before.  If this plan is successful, Aristide will continue to reinvest in his business and build a secure future for his business.

Kamran is asking for a loan of 2000 AZN to update his merchandise. He hopes that having more (and newer) merchandise in his store will help him be more competitive. This would be his first loan.

loans.name: Tim

texts.en: Mrs. C., 49, is employed as a commune consultant advisor in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She is a widow and doesn’t have any children. Her nephew helps be responsible for the family by selling food ingredients, plastics, and some other kitchen accessories. C. has been building a new house for a long time but construction has not been completed due to lack of funds. For this reason, C. has requested a loan to assist her to continue building this new house. This is the second loan she has requested.

loans.use: To continue building her new house

loans.name: Kanou Group

texts.fr:
Kanou est un regroupement de quatre femmes de la ville de Yangasso préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont  connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 32 ans et une moyenne de 6  enfants par femme. 
Elles mènent différentes activités commerciales: vente de produits divers, de fruits et légumes, d’habits, de condiments etc.
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidés d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois ans. Le groupe est à son 6ème  cycle de prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
Les femmes du groupe  achètent leurs marchandises à San et à Koutiala.  Elles vendent au marché de Yangasso et dans les foires environnantes et dans les villages environnants de la ville de San.
Djeneba S., le chef du groupe, est très connue à Yangasso à travers son activité d’achats et de ventes de fruits et légumes. 
Elle s’approvisionne hebdomadairement au  grand marché de Koutiala ville. 
Avec son nouveau  prêt, elle compte acheter, 20 sacs de pomme de terre, 1 sac d’avocat,  50kg de pois de terre, 6 cartons de banane plantain. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 12500FCFA tandis  que les autres membres comptent sur un bénéfice  mensuel de 11500FCFA profit qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans les activités et aussi venir en aide aux conjoints.
texts.en:
'Kanou' is a group of four women from the town of Yangasso, San prefecture (fourth administrative region of Mali). They met because of being related and/or neighbors. They have an average age of 32 and on average, six children each. They have various businesses selling different things: fruit and vegetables, clothing, condiments, etc. In order to expand their businesses, the members decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. They are on their sixth solidarity loan (group loan). They buy their merchandise in San and Koutiala. They make their sales at the market of Yangasso and in the surrounding weekly markets, and the villages surrounding the town of San. Djeneba S., the group leader, is well known in Yangasso for buying and selling fruit and vegetables. She stocks up weekly at the big open-air market of Koutiala town. With her new loan she intends to buy 20 sacks of potatoes, one sack of avocados, 50 kg of Bambara peas, and 6 cases of plantains. She hopes to make a monthly profit of 12,500 F CFA whereas the other members expect to make a monthly profit of 11,500 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the loan and reinvest in their businesses and also to help their husbands support their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fruit and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Marie Solange

texts.en:
Marie Solange is 32 years old and is married with one child who is 13 years old. Marie Solange is commonly known in the business of selling a variety of drinks in her pub and this is her fourth successful year in this business. She runs her business from 6 a.m. until late in the evening hours.

Marie Solange is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through adding more drinks and starting to roast goat meat in her pub. With the use of this loan, she will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business and build a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy a variety of drinks and goat meat for her pub

loans.name: Cham

texts.en:
Cham R. is 32 years old and a resident of Siem Reap province. She earns a living weaving bamboo purses and farming rice. Another source of family income comes from her husband's own small business. He has various musical instruments, speakers, media players and a generator, which he uses to provide a service for wedding parties and other ceremonies. Additionally, he sometimes goes to fish in the river.
Mrs. Cham R. finds it hard to travel anywhere because she has no vehicle, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike to provide transport for her family. She also intends to use some of the loan to buy a small machine to supply electricity for the family’s use.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and a small machine to supply electricity

loans.name: Peace Kwagala Juliet Group

texts.en:
K. Juliet is a 35-year-old businesswoman. She is married with eight children, five of whom are in school. She also takes care of two orphans, one of whom is in school.
Juliet has run a retail shop business for over ten years. She is using her loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, and so forth for resale. Her dreams are to improve her capital and educate her children up to university level.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, etc.

loans.name: Eddie

texts.en:
Eddie J., S.., is from the village of Nungnungan, Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 38 years old. Eddie is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Eddie raises crops. Primarily, he plants and harvests rice for sale. Eddie has been engaged in his business for over 17 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2006, Eddie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. He hoped to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Eddie is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Eddie from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Mr. Un C., age 54, makes a living driving a taxi trailer-motorcycle, picking up his passengers in and around his community for fees. He currently earns an average of $3 a day and has been running his business for years. Beside this, he raises poultry in a stall next to his house for extra profit. 

Un C. is the father of three school-aged children. His wife sells a few grocery items to earn a living. She is also a good housewife who cooks delicious meals. 

This is the second cycle of loans Un C. has pursued.  He will be using this loan to help increase his wife's business capital and decorate a taxi trailer-motorcycle.

loans.use: To help increase his wife's business capital and decorate a taxi trailer-motorcycle.

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badenya est un regroupement de cinq femmes de la ville de San qui se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 28 ans et une moyenne de 3  enfants. 
Elles mènent différentes activités commerciales: vente de produits divers, des condiments alimentaires, de beignet, de la restauration etc. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidés d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur  2ème  cycle de prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
Les femmes du groupe Badenya  achètent leurs marchandises à San et à Yangasso.  Elles effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Yangasso  et dans les villages environnants de la ville de Yangasso.
 Tedi G. est le membre du groupe qui fait de la restauration et c’est elle qui sert le maximum  de passagers et routiers de Yangasso.
Elle compte  acheter, 200 kg de riz, 1 seau de pâte d’arachide,  un panier de tomate, 10 litres d’huile, 2 paquets de maggi, 2kg de sel, 30 kg d’oignons et des légumes. Elle prépare dans sa gargote tous les plats alimentaires du Mali. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 22 000 FCFA par mois tandis que les autres membres compte sur un profit mensuel de 19500 FCFA.  
Elles utiliseront leur revenu dans les dépenses de leur famille et dans les affaires.
texts.en:
This Badenya group brings together five women from the town of San who met through being related and/or neighbors. They are all married, and their average age is 28 with each having 3 children on average. They have various commercial activities: sale of different items, condiments, fritters, and cooked food. To grow their businesses, the members decided to join the loan group of Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The women of the Badenya group buy their merchandise in San and Yangasso. They make their sales at the market of Yangasso and in the surrounding villages. Tedi G. is the group member who sells cooked food and it is she who serves a maximum of passengers and long-distance drivers from Yangasso. She intends to buy 200 kg of rice, one bucket of peanut butter, a basket of tomatoes, 10 liters of oil, 2 packets of Maggi cubes, 2 kg of salt, 30 kg of onions, and some vegetables. At her little snack bar, she prepares all the traditional dishes of Mali. She expects to make a profit of 22,000 F CFA per month, whereas the other members expect to make a profit of 19,500 F CFA. They will use their income for family expenses and their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ingredients for preparing cooked food

loans.name: Sok's Group

texts.en:
There are four low-income people who have jointly requested this loan. 

Mrs. Sok S., 48, is the leader of the group. She operates a handicraft trade out of her home, selling items of furniture that are made from water hyacinth. She is married to Om Navy, 51, who is a district consultant adviser. The couple has five teenage children, one of whom is working as internal staff for an organization. Sok S. would like to repair her existing house, which breaks down often. Therefore, Sok S. would like to ask for a loan in order to mend her house. 

The other borrowers are: 

P. will purchase a net and trap for fishing. 

R. will buy more tools to fish.

H., a fish catcher, requests a loan to decorate her house.

loans.use: To mend her house.

loans.name: Dédé

texts.fr: Cette femme est âgée de 35 ans,  elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente des articles de quincaillerie, elle exerce ce commerce depuis 2005, actuellement son stock est en épuisement, voulant  se réapprovisionner, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de divers articles de quincaillerie.
texts.en:
This woman is 35 years old and has been involved in the sale of hardware items since 2005. Her stock level is currently low and so she is seeking a loan from WAGES in order to replenish it with more hardware items.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase hardware items

loans.name: Tuch

texts.en:
Mr. S. is highly skilled at making ferrous cask, which is how he earns a living. He receives a lot of flattery from his clients, who recognize what a good quality product he makes. 

S. was married, but divorced his wife when his child was young. He now takes care of a teenage child who attends the public local school. 

Recently, S. has been getting many orders from his customers, but he is now concerned that he doesn’t have any raw materials to make casks for the need of his client. Therefore, S. would like to ask a loan to use as capital to order to buy the required article.      
.

loans.use: To buy materials to make sets of cask

loans.name: Peace Nabadande Faima Group

texts.en:
N. Faima is married and blessed with one child. She is twenty-three years of age. 

She is involved in a retail shop business which she has been operating for over two years. She is using the loan to purchase retail shop items such as rice, flour, drinks, sugar, soap, salt, and so forth to add more stock into her business. She is an encouraging business lady whose dream is to educate her child.

loans.use: To purchase rice, flour, drinks, sugar, soap, salt, etc. for her shop

loans.name: Vodou Houndjenouko

texts.fr: cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de pagnes,elle fait ce commerce de façon ambulante.elle s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé ou ce commerce est très développé, elle a une grande expérience de cette activité ce qui lui de bien gérer son commerce. elle veut agrandir son commerce raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour s'acheter des pagnes de différentes qualité.elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants
texts.en: Vodou A. sells pagne cloth to make money. She walks around to sell the cloth rather than operating her business from a fixed location. She buys the cloth in the grand market in Lomé, where the fabric market is well-developed, and has lots of experience in this sector, which helps her to manage her business effectively. She wants to grow her business, which is why she is taking out her first loan with WAGES in order to buy different-quality pagne cloth to sell. She is married and has three children.

loans.use: achat de pagnes

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Petty trading like the sale of groceries is widespread in Ghana because it is easy to start. It usually begins with table-top selling and then grows to become a kiosk and eventually becomes supermarket. Helena is one of such entrepreneurs who have been trading in groceries like biscuits, bottled water, candies, can foods, rice, cooking oil, toiletries, etc., for the past three years. She sells in a metal store near her community market, hoping that, one day, she will be able to grow her business into a supermarket. She is excited to be taking out the loan which she plans to invest in purchasing groceries in bulk to serve her customers. She anticipates increasing her profit level and also expanding her market.

Apart from being a vibrant entrepreneur, Helena is also married and she is the mother of three children from age 3-11 years. She describes herself as an industrious woman who is able to combine household demands with business demands.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi  est un regroupement de cinq femmes de la ville de San qui se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 29 ans et une moyenne de 4  enfants. Elles mènent différentes activités commerciales: vente de produits divers, de poissons et de céréales. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidés d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso sont  à leur  2ème  cycle de prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi achètent leurs marchandises à San.  Elles vendent au marché de San et dans les différents quartiers de la ville de San.
Bintou Traoré qui la présidente du groupe est une vendeuse de poissons sous plusieurs formes, fumé, séché et frais. 
Elle s’approvisionne avec les demi grossistes à San pour revendre en détail et au comptant. 
Elle compte acheter  journalièrement, 30kg de poisson frais et 25kg de poisson fumé. Elle est très sollicitée par ses clients  pour la qualité de ses marchandises et compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 23000FCFA tandis que les autres membres  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice de 21000FCFA par mois. Leurs bénéfices seront utilisés pour rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a group of five women from the village of San who met through neighbours and family. They are all around 29 years old and married with 4 children. They all have different jobs: selling various products, fish and cereals. In order to enlarge their businesses, the members decided to seek a second loan from Soro Yiriwaso. They purchase their goods at San and sell them at San and in the various quarters of the town. Bintou Traoré, the group's president, sells various types of fish - smoked, dried and fresh. She sources her wares from wholesalers at San and sells them for cash. She aims to purchase 30kg of fresh fish and 25kg of smoked fish per day. Her goods are sought-after for their quality, and she aims to generate a monthly profit of 23,000 FCFA, the other members of the group generating 21,000 FCFA per month. All their profits will be used to repay the loan and reinvest into business activities.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fish

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en: Mrs. Choeun N. has been selling different kinds of vegetables at the market for years and typically generates an income of $3 per day. Choeun N. has been married for a long time and has seven children. Three of her children are married and four are single. Most of her children work at different jobs, while her husband assists her in delivering vegetables to the market. In order to earn extra income and make the business more successful, Choeun N. is applying for a loan to improve the capital of her vegetable sale trade.

loans.use: To improve the capital of her vegetable sale trade.

loans.name: Help Your Friends Group

texts.en:
Selena J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Help Your Friends.  She is 35 years old, single and has four children who range from 2 to 16 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties. She cares for two siblings.

For 16 years, she has been operating a beauty salon on Ashmun Street in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She says that customers are attracted to her business because she talks to them in a friendly manner.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more hair products.
 
Her hope is to improve her business and take good care of her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more hair products.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya est un regroupement de cinq femmes de la ville de Tominian  (quatrième région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans et une moyenne de 4  enfants. 
Elles mènent différentes activités commerciales: vente d’articles divers, d’habits et de condiments. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidés d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur  2ème  cycle de prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
Les femmes du groupe Danaya s’approvisionnent en marchandises à San et  à Bobo.  Elles vendent au marché de Tominian  et dans les villages environnants de la ville de Tominian.
Dans le groupe figure une femme du nom de Mariam B. qui fait la navette entre Tominian et le Burkina dans le cadre de son activité. En effet elle fait l’achat et la vente des tissus en soie et des draps de lit. 
Avec son prêt elle compte acheter, 5 balles de tissus en soie et 6 douzaines  de draps de lit.
Elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 42000FCFA tandis que les autres du groupe espèrent sur un profit mensuel de 39000 FCFA   
En dehors des remboursements de prêt elles utilisent une partie de leur revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses de leur famille.
texts.en:
The Danaya group is made up of five women from Tominian (the fourth largest administrative region of Mali) who met through family and neighbours. They are all around 42 years-old, married with four children on average. They are involved in various business activities: selling various products, clothes and condiments. In order to upscale their business, the members have decided to seek a second loan from Soro Yiriwaso. The women in the Danaya group source their goods from San and Bobo, and sell them at the Tominian market and in the surrounding villages. A group member called Mariam B. takes the ferry between Tominian and Burkina in order to trade her goods. She buys and sells silk and bed linen. She hopes to use her loan to purchase 5 rolls of silk and 6 dozen bedsheets, and aims to generate monthly loans of 42,000 FCFA and the other women aim to generate 39,000 FCFA. Apart from repaying the loans they will use part of their revenue to see to their family's needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes

loans.name: Immacule

texts.en:
Immacule is 57 years old, married with three children, and she takes care of four dependents. She lives by selling a variety of goods in her shop and the hours of her business are from 6 a.m. until late in the evening hours.

Although Immacule has been in this business for about eight years, her capital is still too low to earn enough profits. To solve this problem, she would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her shop through adding a variety of foodstuffs including rice, beans, peas, Irish potatoes, etc.

With these additional goods for sale in her shop, Immacule will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business and start saving for her future.

loans.use: To buy a variety of foodstuffs for her store

loans.name: Depend On God Group

texts.en:
Fatu F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Depend On God.  She is 47 years old, married and has three children who range from 16 to 25 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties. She cares for two siblings. All of her children attend school.

For 20 years, she has been selling socks, underclothes, children clothes, head ties and gents wear at Waterside Market in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She says customers are attracted to her business because she talks to them in a friendly manner.

She plans to use her 10,400 Liberian dollar portion of this 52,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more socks, underclothes, children clothes, head ties and gents' wear. 
 
Her goal is to improve her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Georgette is inset at lower right because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more socks, underclothes, children clothes, head ties and gents wear.

loans.name: Djekadi Group

texts.fr:
Djekadi  est un regroupement de femmes de la ville de Tominian qui se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 55 ans et une moyenne de 6  enfants par femme. 
Elles mènent différentes activités commerciales: vente d’articles divers, beignets et de condiments. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidés d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
Les femmes du groupe Djekadi  achètent leurs marchandises à San et au Burkina Faso.  Elles vendent au marché de Tominian  et dans les villages environnants de la ville de Tominian.
Fatoumata D. est la vendeuse de beignet du groupe Djekadi, elle exerce au grand marché de Tominian et s’approvisionne en farines, huiles et accessoires au même grand marché de la ville de San. 
Elle compte acheter, 10 sacs de farine, 5 bidons d’huile et une grande quantité en produits accessoires (sucre, levure, sel de cuisine, arômes etc). 
Chaque soir Madame Fatoumata D. prend sa farine et la pétrie avec de l’eau, des œufs, du beurre, du sucre et de la levure. Après avoir bien mélangé ces ingrédients elle ferme bien la pâte jusqu’à 6 heures du matin, heure à laquelle elle commence à frire ses beignets.
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 17000FCFA par mois tandis que les autres membres comptent sur un profit mensuel de 14500FCFA.  
En dehors des remboursements de prêt elles utilisent une partie de leur revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses de leur famille. 
Dans les jours à venir elles comptent avoir des prêts de montant élevés pour étendre les activités.
texts.en:
Djekadi is a group of women from the city of Tominian who know one another through ties of kinship and community.  All of them are married and average 55 years of age and six children each.  These women run different businesses: selling various goods, beignets, and condiments.   To increase the size of their businesses, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program and are now on their second solidarity loan cycle (group loan).  They purchase their merchandise in San and in Burkina Faso. They sell their goods at the Tominian market and in the villages surrounding Tominian.   Fatoumata D. is a beignet seller in the group.  She operates at the big market of Tominian and gets her supplies of flour, oil, and extras, like the others, at the big market of San City.  She plans on buying ten sacks of flour, five containers of oil, and a large quantity of extras (sugar, leavening, kitchen salt, flavorings, etc.)  Each evening, Fatoumata takes her flour and kneads it with some water, eggs, butter, sugar, and leavening.  After mixing these ingredients, she covers the dough until 6:00 AM, at which time she starts frying her beignets.   Fatoumata hopes to make monthly profit of 17,000 francs CFA per month, while the other members are counting on monthly profit of 14,500 francs. Besides repaying the loan, the group members use part of their revenues to meet family expenses.  In the days to come, the women plan on obtaining bigger loans to expand their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ingredients to make beignets

loans.name: Ayélé Akpédzé

texts.fr:
cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de cartes de recharges, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2008, afin d'atteindre un plus grand nombre de clients elle fait ce commerce de façon ambulante, sa clientèle se compose de toute personne. elle veut agrandir son stock de marchandises raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de cartes de recharges illico,togocel et moov.
elle est célibataire et c'est avec le revenu de son commerce qu'elle subvient à ses propres charges
texts.en:
This woman has a revenue-generating retail business selling recharge cards for mobile phones.  She has been in this business since 2008.  In order to attain a larger number of customer, she operates door-to-door.  Her customer base includes anyone.  She wants to expand her stock of merchandise.  For this reason, she is requesting a loan from WAGES for buying ILLICO, TogoCell, and Moov cards. She is unmarried, and with the revenue from her commerce, she supports herself. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying mobile phone cards

loans.name: Sinignessigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sinignèssigui  est constitué de cinq femmes de la ville de Tominian (quatrième Région  administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et une moyenne de 4 enfants par femme. 
Elles mènent différentes activités commerciales: vente de produits divers, de condiments alimentaires, de fruits et de céréales. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres décident d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 1er cycle  de prêt solidaire. 
Les femmes du groupe Sinignèssigui  achètent leurs marchandises à San et Bamako (capitale du Mali) et vendent au marché de Tominian et dans les foires de Mandiaky et environnants.  
Parmi les membres du groupe se trouve une femme du nom de Mama M. qui est sollicitée par ses clients pour la qualité de ses condiments alimentaires. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako en gros  pour effectuer ses ventes à Tominian en demi gros, au comptant et en détail à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 25 cartons de maggi de toutes sortes, 50 petits sacs de sel, 120kg de l’ail, 70kg de poivre et 15kg de laurier. 
Madame Mama M. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 19000FCFA qui servira à rembourser le prêt,  agrandir les activités et venir en aide aux conjoints pour les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The Sinignèssigui group is made up of five women from the town of Tominian (fourth administrative region of Mali). They met through relatives and neighbors. They are all married and average 35 years of age, with an average of four children per woman. They carry out different commercial activities: the sale of various products, condiments, fruits and cereals. In order to grow their activities, the members of the group decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program, and they are on their first group loan with the institution. The women in the Sinignèssigui group buy their goods in San and Bamako (the capital of Mali), and they sell at the market in Tominian and at the fairs in Mandiaky and the surrounding areas. Among the members of the group there is a lady called Mama M., who is in demand from her customers for the quality of her condiments. She gets her supplies wholesale in Bamako and sells them in Tominian on a partly wholesale basis, for cash and on a retail basis to a customer base which is essentially made up of women. She is planning to use her loan to buy 25 cartons of all different types of Maggi stock cubes, 50 bags of salt, 120 kg of garlic, 70kg of pepper and 15kg of bay leaves. Mrs. Mama M. expects to make a monthly profit of 19,000FCFA, which will be used to repay her loan, expand her business and help her husband out with the family expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments

loans.name: Yaovi

texts.en: This man has a general store in his hometown in Togo. He is 35 years old and is married with two children. His wife also has her own business. He has been in business since 2008 and is requesting a loan in order to purchase more products for resale in his store.

loans.use: Purchase more products for resale in his store

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Leather for manufacturing shoes, belts, and 'dressing bags' is obtained from animal skins which are produced in large scale in Northern Ghana. The skins are dried with the sun's heat for days to be hardened and then refined into leather which becomes the raw material for shoes, belts and bag making. Selling leather is a lucrative business for women like Cecilia. She has been purchasing leather and adhesives in bulk and retails them to shoe makers and cobblers in her community for the past two years. She plans to invest the loan to purchase additional leather and adhesives to increase her wares. She anticipates increasing her profit level and also expanding her market.

Cecilia is married to a radio presenter and together they have two children of ages 19 and 14 years. She describes herself as hard-working and a resourceful mother.

loans.use: To purchase leather and adhesives in bulk for resale

loans.name: Faithful People Group

texts.en:
Miatta G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Faithful People.  She is 44 years old, married and has six children who range from 10 to 23 years old.  She was not able to attend school due to poverty.  She cares for two siblings.  All of her children attend school.

For four years, she has been selling fish at Gbenbga Town Market outside Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 8,500 Liberian dollar portion of this 42,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more fish.
 
Her goal is to improve her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more fish

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Melvin J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is Able. He is 30 years old, married and has three children who range from 2 to 9 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties. 

All of his children are in school and he also cares for one sibling.

For six years, he has been selling gospel and sports posters on the Old Road in Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 39,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more gospel and sports posters.
 
His dream is to expand his business, save some money and go back to school.

loans.use: To buy more gospel and sports posters

loans.name: Women Of Trust Group

texts.en:
Regina S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Women of Trust.  She is 40 years old, married and has five children who range from 8 to 26 years old.  She is a university graduate.  She cares for two siblings. 

For four years, she has been buying fish in bulk and selling it in several places outside of town.

She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 45,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more fish.
 
Her goal is to improve her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more fish.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A. prepares Fante kenkey for sale at Abura. She has no educational background. She is a widow and has six dependents.

Efua has been in the kenkey production business for some time now and is responsible for the upkeep of her family. Her loan will be used to buy extra bags of maize to prepare Fante kenkey for distribution to her customers. She hopes to use the new earnings from her business to save to educate her children.

To prepare her kenkey, Efua buys maize from the market and soaks it in enough water to soften the maize. She washes the maize on the third day and sends it to the mill to be milled. She then makes a mixture of dough out of the milled wet corn and leaves it to prove (ferment) until the next day.

Efua divides the proved dough into two parts, uses one part for her firm half-cooked dough (mixes it with water to get it in a porridge form, cooks it for some time to get a firm mixture or texture of the dough) and then mixes the rest of the uncooked dough with the half-cooked dough. She moulds it into balls and wraps each ball in corn husk. She then cooks them again till they becomes soft enough to eat.

Kenkey can be eaten with various kinds of sauces, such as pepper sauce, with fried or roasted fish, roasted chicken, roasted turkey or any other kind of meat or fish.

The photo was taken when Efua had just lit the fire under the kenkey to boil it to get it ready for distribution.

loans.use: To buy extra bags of maize to prepare more Fante kenkey

loans.name: Self Help Group

texts.en:
Oretha J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Self Help.  She is 47 years old, is single and has five children who range from 7 to 28 years old.  She was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to financial difficulties. 

Two of her children attend university and she also cares for two siblings.

For six years, she has been selling rice, flour, oil and sugar in New Matilda Estate, Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 38,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more rice, flour, oil and sugar.
 
Her hope is to improve her business and take good care of her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more rice, flour, oil and sugar.

loans.name: Adjouwa

texts.en:
This client sells groceries to make her living. She is married to a man who is an accountant, and has been unable to keep her store well-stocked. So, she has requested a loan from WAGES in order to buy groceries to sell in her store. 

Cette femme exerce comme activité la vente de produits d'alimentation générale, elle est mariée à un monsieur qui est comptable, elle fait face à une rupture de stock et souhaite se réapprovisionner, raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de divers produits d'alimentation générale.

loans.use: Buying groceries for sale in her store

loans.name: Kokovi

texts.en: This woman owns a bar in her hometown in Togo. She is an experienced entrepreneur; she is sixty years old and has had her bar for almost thirty years. She calls her place “Bar La Source.” In addition to running the bar, this woman is a widow with four children. She’s an experienced borrower with WAGES. She has requested her third loan from the organization to help her purchase soft drinks, beer, and other beverages.

loans.use: Purchase soft drinks, beer and other beverages to sell in her bar

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi A. prepares tea and fried eggs for sale in the mornings and evenings at Abura. She sets up her table in the morning around 6 a.m. to 10 a.m. and comes back in the evening around 6 p.m. and closes around 10 p.m.

Esi has received senior high education. She is a single parent and has two children. She responsibly takes care of her children. Her loan will be used to buy more bread, eggs and provisions to prepare and sell. She hopes to use the new revenues from her business to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To buy more bread, eggs and provisions to prepare and sell

loans.name: Cartas

texts.en:
Cartas is 42 years old and is a widow. She owns a shop selling a variety of goods. She has owned this shop for about three years and the hours of her business are from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Cartas is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase a large quantity of goods to sell. She hopes that, through these additional goods, she will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business and start saving for a better future.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for her store such as rice, different types of flour, sugar, rice, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose U. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and beans at the market and is requesting a loan to stock maize flour and dried fish as well. Rose is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has two children and one of her children goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house that she can rent out. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock maize flour and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Geronima Esperanza

texts.es: Geronima ha realizado varios financiamientos con Fundación León 2000, por lo que agradece la oportunidad que le brindaron en confiar en ella. Tiene la actividad económica de venta de tortillas. Inicio hace 42 años con muy poco capital de trabajo, como una búsqueda de fuente de ingresos alternativos, por lo que ella misma logro obtener su propia fama en sus deliciosas tortillas. El financiamiento es destinado para capital de trabajo para la compra de leña, cal y maíz.
texts.en:
Geronima has had several loans with the Fundación León 2000. She is grateful for the opportunity they offered when they put their trust in her. Her economic activity is selling tortillas. She started 42 years ago with very little working capital, seeking a way to have an alternate source of income. She acheived her own fame for her delicous tortillas. The loan is for working capital to purchase firewood, lime and corn.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is in the business of selling irish potatoes and cassava tubers at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of onions to sell. Susan is 41 and a widow with five school-age children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock bags of onions to sell

loans.name: Hayat

texts.en:
Hayat J. is in the business of selling charcoal and a local brew at home. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Hayat is 39 and married to a business man. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Ongima

texts.en:
Ongima Emmnuel is in the business of selling groundnuts and maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans and pulses (lentils) to sell. Ongima is 42  and a widow. She has 7 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock bags of beans and pulses (lentils) to sell

loans.name: Yamileth Del Rosario

texts.es: Yamilet Del Rosario tiene 30 años, su actividad es una pulpería. La ubicación de su humilde negocio, es en su vivienda pues sus vecinos llegan a comprar los diferentes productos que ofrece como golosinas, detergentes, jugos, azúcar, aceites, frijoles, leña, papel higiénico entre otras cosas. Ella ha demostrado ser una persona muy emprendedora y que disfruta de su actividad y del momento de interactuar con sus clientes, pues esto le proporciona más confianza. El destino del crédito es para la compra de materia prima necesaria para su trabajo. El deseo de Yamilet es transformar su pequeña pulpería en una distribuidora.
texts.en:
Yamilet Del Rosario is 30 years old, and her business is a general store. This humble shop is located in her home; her neighbors come by to purchase the range of products she offers, including snacks, detergents, juices, sugar, cooking oil, beans, firewood and bathroom tissue, among other things. Yamilet has shown herself to be a very enterprising person who enjoys her work, especially her interactions with customers, which give her increased confidence. The loan will be used to buy supplies that are necessary for her work. Yamilet's desire is to convert her small general store into a distribution business.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Helida

texts.en:
Helida T is currently in the business of selling various items in the shop such as bags of salt, biscuits, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and boxes of soap to sell. Helida is 43 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 6 children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of sugar and boxes of soap to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary S. is currently in the business of selling bags of sugar, beans, and maize flour at the store and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of such goods to sell. Mary is 49 years old and is widowed. She has 8 children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a motorbike and build a house for rental purposes.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of such goods to sell

loans.name: Amuna

texts.en:
Amuna L. is currently in the business of selling dresses, pairs of trousers and bedsheets and is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets to sell.  Amuna is 40 years old and is widowed. She has 7 children, and 3 of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bedsheets to sell

loans.name: Los Tres Pisos Group

texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Los Tres Pisos” and it is composed of 15 members from the city of Temuco. The group members are seamstresses (making and selling things like curtains, tablecloths, and hats), artisans (creating products like jewelry and wooden accessories), clothing salespeople, grocers, and bakers of empanadas and cakes.

The group member interviewed was Ingrid, who is the bank’s president. In the photo she is in the center of the back row wearing a red sleeveless vest over a black shirt. She sells a variety of products, things like hangers and card games, and changes her stock depending on what’s in style, for example she may sell a game or a product specific to a particular holiday. Ingrid sells from a post located in the central zone of part of Temuco where she lives. Her post does not have a roof, so when it rains she does other sorts of work, like daycare or cooking. Ingrid plans on investing this loan in merchandise for her business: heating packs, hangers, and other novelty products she finds.

Ingrid’s dream is to have a place to sell which is protected from the rain, ideally in her home. Her greatest motivation are her children, 18 and 16, to whom she hopes to provide everything they need. Her oldest son is in his first year of the university.

What Ingrid has enjoyed the most of Fondo Esperanza is the group work she does with her communal bank and the comfort she feels in the meetings because of the sincerity of all the members; this has allowed them to get to know one another very well and support each other.

Temuco is the capital of the Araucanía region. It is located 670 kilometres south of Santiago (the capital of Chile) and possesses a series of lakeside spa resorts and striking native flora and fauna. This region is also noteworthy for being the region where 50% of Chile's existing indigenous Mapuche community live, some of whom are members of Fondo Esperanza communal banks.

loans.use: to buy more hangers, bags, and holiday novelties to resell

loans.name: Silvia Argentina

texts.es: Silvia Argentina tiene 57 años  hace  mas de 16 años que tiene esta pulpería, inicio por la necesidad generar ingresos para su familia, por lo que ha sabido manejar muy bien esta actividad pues fue por medio de ella que logro sacar adelante a sus 8 hijos, con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado aumentar sus ganancias y proporcionarles a sus hijos lo que más necesitaban en este negocio aprendió muchas cosas, con sus clientes pues algunas veces solicitaban nuevos productos y ella tiene que comprar diversidad en productos. El crédito será invertido en materia prima granos básicos, dulces, detergentes, gaseosas, cosméticos entre otras cosas. Sueña con tener otro negocio que sea herencia para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Silvia Argentina is 57 years old and has run this store for more than16 years. She started the store out of the need to generate income for her family. She has learned very well how to run the business, the result being that she has been able to help her 8 children move ahead. With much effort she has been able to increase her earnings and provide for her children that which they needed most. In this business she learned many things. Her clients, for example, at times request new products and she has to buy a variety of inventory. The loan will be invested in supplies like basic grains, sweets, detergents, soft drinks, and cosmetics among other items. She hopes to have another business that will be an inheritance for her children,

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Zafiro Group

texts.es:
Este  grupo se llama  “Zafiro” nombre elegido por ser una piedra preciosa. Todos ellos viven en la ranchería Vainilla, Nacajuca, Tabasco. Esta integrado por dos hombres y tres mujeres. Efrén C. T., su negocio es una frutería. Rodolfo P. G. se dedica a la venta de zapatos marca impuls. Rosa O. H. se dedica a vender quesos de manera ambulante a las abarroteras del municipio de Nacajuca. María Esperanza F. L. el crédito lo quiere para poner una tiendita en su domicilio. Brenda del Carmen F. O. se dedica a la venta de zapatos para dama, viaja al estado de Yucatán para comprar su mercancía y la vende de manera ambulante y también por pedidos que le hacen sus clientes fijos. 

Don Efrén es el representante del grupo, es casado, tiene 4 hijos. Efrén  tiene su frutería de nombre “La Frutana” local ubicado en las afueras del mercado público del municipio de Nacajuca, negocio familiar que atiende junto con su esposa e hijos, antes  su esposa trabajaba en una frutería que era de su hermana,  hace  4 años  decidieron tener una propia. Su negocio les rinde ganancias que le ayudan  para la educación de sus hijos. 

Con este crédito,  quiere comprar papaya, calabaza, tomate, frijol, cebolla, melón, manzana, piña, cilantro, pera, guineo (plátano), uva, pera, también frijol, maíz, cilantro, pasta, etc.  Su meta para el futuro es dar un mejor nivel de vida a sus hijos y que estos terminen una carrera universitaria. 

Son un grupo familiar entusiasta, muy unidos, emprendedores con deseos de superarse.  Están muy contentos  y se sienten afortunados por la ayuda que  le brinda la Fundación y KIVA al creer en sus negocios, al otorgarles un crédito que les servirá para invertirlo en cada una de sus actividades económicas.
texts.en:
This group is called “Zafiro” [Sapphire], and this name was chosen because it is a precious stone. All of them live in the town of Vainilla, Nacajuca, Tabasco. It is composed of two men and three women. Efrén C. T. sells fruits. Rodolfo P. G. sells Impuls brand shoes. Rosa O. H. sells cheeses by going from grocery store to grocery store in the municipality of Nacajuca. María Esperanza F. L. wants to use the loan to open a small store in her house. Brenda del Cármen F. O. sells women’s shoes. She goes to the state of Yucatán to buy her merchandise and then sells as a traveling merchant and also fills orders from regular customers. Efrén is a representative of the group. He is married and has 4 children. Efrén has a fruit store named “La Frutana”, which is located on the outer edges of the public market in the municipality Nacajuca. It is a family business that he tends to with the help of his wife and children. His wife used to work in a fruit store that belongs to her sister. Four years ago they decided to open their own store. The business provides them income that helps them with their children’s education expenses. With this loan Efrén wants to buy papaya, squash, tomatoes, beans, onion, cantaloupes, apples, pineapples, cilantro, pears, bananas, grapes, corn, pasta, etc. His goal for the future is to provide a better standard of living for his children and for them to finish university. This is a family-oriented group that is enthusiastic, united, hardworking, and with a great desire to get ahead. They are very happy and feel fortunate because of the support the Foundation and Kiva provide them by believing in their businesses and granting them a loan that will allow them to invest in each of their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy papaya, squash, tomatoes, beans, onion, cantaloupes, apples, pineapples, cilantro, pears, bananas, grapes, corn, pasta, etc.

loans.name: Karen Valesca

texts.es: Karen Valesca tiene 24 años es casada y tiene 1 hijo menor de edad. La señora tiene ubicada en su casa de habitación una pulpería muy surtida, la cual es administrada personalmente por ella, además de esto su mama le ayuda a comprar la mercadería en el mercado. Sus ventas son siempre de contado, igualmente tiene que comprar al contado. Ella empezó con este negocio desde hace 2 años y medio, este dio inicio cuando su esposo estaba desempleado, Ahora su esposo trabaja como despachador en una distribuidora, sin embargo ellos observaron que el negocio era rentable, por lo que decidieron continuar con el mismo. El crédito solicitado por la señora será invertido en la compra de inventario para la pulpería, principalmente granos básicos, ya que desea surtirla. Su sueño siempre ha sido llegar a tener una vivienda propia, ya que donde viven actualmente le pertenece a su mama.
texts.en:
Karen Valesca is 24, married and has one young child. She has a small, well-stocked local store in the house where she lives. She runs it herself, and her mother helps her to buy the merchandise in the market. Her sales are always in cash, and likewise she has to buy in cash. She began this business 2 and a half years ago, when her husband was unemployed. Her husband now works as a delivery man in a distribution company, but they saw that the business was profitable and so they decided to continue with it. The requested loan will be invested in the purchase of inventory for the store, principally basic grains, since she wants to stock up. Karen's dream has always been to own her own home, as the one they currently live in belongs to her mother.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital-general store

loans.name: Zamu

texts.en:
She is a 57-year-old widowed mother of five children. Seven years is the time that sociable and good-humored N. Zamu has taken to become fully well-grounded in her brickmaking enterprise, normally thought of as a preserve of men. She has done her utmost to firmly establish a niche for herself, albeit with many challenges.

One overriding challenge which has threatened to throw Zamu’s business out of gear has been the inconsistency in terms of customer demand with every passing season. She is a woman who treads softly and this attribute has helped her overcome most of these drawbacks. With enough stock, after her late husband had prevailed upon her, she began her business. At present, she makes monthly profits amounting to 600,000 shillings.

With the construction boom around the country, Zamu can rest assured that her future will be a flourishing one. With this loan, she says she wants to add to her existing capital. That, in essence, means she is going to buy more brickmaking, maintainence, and storage equipment.

In the photo, N. Zamu appears with Ssenteza Jude, a Credit Officer.

loans.use: To purchase more brickmaking, maintainence and storage equipment

loans.name: Alegria Group

texts.es:
EL grupo del que vamos a platicar se llama “Alegria”, el cual las integrantes de identifican mucho con este nombre por que son muy alegres, sus intregrantes son: Senorina Dávila, Guiumar, Josefa reina, Maria Lourdes, Liliana, francisca faustina todas ella se dedican a la elaboración de dulce típico (alegrias, palanquetas y obleas)

    La Sra. Senorina desde hace 10 años de dedica a la venta de dulce típico cuenta con 42 años de edad, actualmente vive con su esposo el Sr. Antonio B. Vidal el es originario de huazulco cuando regresaron a vivir a esta comunidad fue entonces cuando ambos y  junto con sus hijos que son 3 iniciaron la venta de este dulces, el mayor se llama Alexci B. Dávila de 22 años de edad (soltero), Alexander B. Dávila de 20 años(soltero) y el pequeño Kevin de 15 años actualmente estudia la preparatoria cursa el 1er grado.

La Sra. Senorina junto con su familia han salido adelante con su negocio de hecho han llegado a tener pedidos grandes y que proveen al estado de puebla, sus hijos le son de gran ayuda, ella tiene 4 años trabajando con Fundacion Realidad y le ha ido muy bien con los créditos que a obtenido y a p adquirir su maquinaria y herramienta para poder trabajar.

El sueño de ella es poder acondicionar bien su taller, donde elabora su dulce, ella quiere agradecer a la Fundacion y a kiva por los créditos que le han otorgado, gracias a ellos a logrado lo que hasta la fecha tiene, y sugiere que haya crédito individuales.
texts.en:
The Group we will discuss is called “Alegria” (Happiness). Its members identify with this name because they are very happy. They are Senorina Dávila, Guiumar, Josefa Reina, Maria Lourdes, Liliana, and Francisca Faustina. All of them manufacture typical sweets (“alegrias, panquetas, and obleas”). Senorina is 42 years old and has been selling sweets for the ten years. She lives with her husband, Antonio, who is originally from Huazulco. When they returned to live in this community, they and their three children began selling sweets. The oldest is named Alexander, age 20 and single; the youngest is Kevin, age 15 and attending his first year of high school. Senorina and her family have come out ahead with their business. They have had large orders from around the state of Puebla and her children have been of great help. She has been working with Fundacion Realidad for four years and things have gone very well for her. She has used the money from past loans to buy tools and machinery that she needs for her work. She hopes to be able to equip her shop well and is very thankful to the foundation and to Kiva for the loans which they have provided in the past.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies and ingredients

loans.name: Mayela Del Socorro

texts.es: Mayela Del Socorro tiene 45 años, es soltera y no tiene hijos. La señora tiene en su casa el negocio de venta de carnes variadas, principalmente carne de pollo y res. Ella ya tiene 2 años y medio de tener este negocio, cabe señalarse este negocio ella lo empezó en una época en que estaba desempleada, actualmente ella tiene trabajo sin embargo ha luchado para mantenerlo pues ha brindado muchas ganancias a la familia. Ella desea este crédito con el objetivo de invertir en la compra de carnes principalmente de pollo, ya que se acerca la fecha del 30 de mayo celebración para el di de la Madre, que son épocas buenas de ventas y es lo que desea aprovechar. Su sueño siempre ha sido llegar a tener un supermercado grande, en la cual no solo venda carnes sino de todo tipo de artículos, a buenos precios para ayudar a las personas.
texts.en:
Mayela Del Socorro is 45 years old, single, and doesn't have children. She runs a business out of her house, where she sells meat, especially chicken and beef. She has already had this business for two and a half years. It should be noted that she started this business during a time when she was unemployed. Now she has work, though she has struggled to maintain it, and it has brought many gains to her family. She hopes to invest this loan in the purchase of meat, especially chicken. The May 30th Mother's Day celebration is soon and it is a very good time for sales, so she would like to take advantage of that. Her dream has always been to eventually have a large supermarket where she would sell not only meat but all types of items, and at good prices to help other people.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase meat (especially chicken) to sell

loans.name: Santos Agustin

texts.es: Santos Agustín tiene 27 años, el se dedica a brindar el servicio musical. El tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación, pues siempre ha buscado la forma de mejorar su negocio y lo ha logrado por medio de los financiamientos que han sido de gran ayuda para que su negocio avance. Sus inicios se dan desde hace 10 pues el siempre está buscando la forma de obtener ingresos como todo padre responsable le brinda a su hijo la educación que el necesita. Es así que el motivo del financiamiento es  para la compra de materia prima como instrumentos musicales, alambres, extensiones, parlantes entre otras cosas. Sueña con seguir manteniendo a su familia por medio de este negocio.
texts.en:
Santos Agustín is 27 years and provides musical services. He has been working with the Foundation for a long time. He has always looked for a way of improving his business and has achieved it through means of funding that have been of great help for the advancement of his business. He began ten years ago but is always looked for a way to obtain income as any responsible father would to provide his son with the education that he needs. This is why his motive for funding is for purchase of raw material such as musical instruments, wire, extensions, and speakers, among other items. He dreams of continuing to maintain his family through this business.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mariano

texts.es:
Mariana de 55 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín de Guayaquil, tiene tres hijos y su esposa vende pollos. El tiene una papelería (llamada en Ecuador “bazar”) con cuadernos, laminas, plumas, y todo tipo de papelería. Esta papelería ya la tiene hace mucho tiempo con la ayuda de su esposa ha podido incrementarla y salir de la crisis que estaba su familia.

Su esposa le ayuda en la papelería y también le ayuda en los gastos del hogar vendiendo pollos, trabajan desde las 07h00am hasta las 22h00pm. Los cuadernos los venden a $ 1.20, plumas a $ 0.40, laminas a $ 0.15. Para poder incrementar la mercadería de su negocio el quiere comprar cuadernos, libros y plumas para la papelería.  

En el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa y sabe que sus hijos han terminados sus estudios.
texts.en:
Mariana is 55 years old, lives in the suburban zone of Fortín de Guayaquil, and has 3 children. His wife sells chickens and he has a stationary store (in Ecuador called a "bazar") with notebooks, prints, pens, and every type of stationary. He's had the store for a long time and with the help of his wife has been able to expand the business and get out of the crisis that his family was in. His wife helps him in the stationary store and also helps with the household expenses by selling chickens. They work from 7:00 A.M. until 10:00 P.M. The notebooks sell for $1.20, pens for $.40, and the prints for $.15. To increase the merchandise the business has, he wants to buy notebooks, books, and pens for the store. In the future he wants to finish constructing his house and know that his children have completed their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy notebooks, books, and pens

loans.name: Honorato

texts.es: Honorato tiene 45 años, es divorciado y tiene dos hijos. Residen en la localidad de Quimbiri, ubicada en la selva tropical cusqueña, donde tiene su propia casa. Honorato recuerda que hace mucho tiempo no tenía nada que ofrecer a su familia, pero sí conocimiento de las técnicas de sembrío y cosecha de Piña, desde entonces empezó a producir y comercializar este producto. Hoy vende su producto a los grandes mayoristas a un precio competitivo, y con los ahorros que obtuvo pudo adquirir un moto carro para ofrecer actualmente el servicio de taxi, de esa manera logró recibir otros ingresos extras. Su fin ahora es diversificar su mercado, por ello su hijo mayor se encarga del cultivo de piña, cuidándolos de las plagas que afecten su producción, siendo al final llevados a los centros de acopio de su misma localidad. Agradece a su familia por el apoyo y ayuda que le dieron en los momentos mas difíciles, por tal motivo es que desea abrir una tienda de venta de ropa, con el propósito de ampliar su mercado y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. Este es su sexto crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con sus obligaciones de pago, además agradece a la institución por la responsabilidad que  ejercen. Con el crédito que solicita lo invertirá en comprar semillas de piña con la necesidad de mejorar en su producción, además desea darle un mantenimiento adecuado a su motocarro.
texts.en:
Honorato is 45, divorced, and has two children. They live in the town of Quimbiri, located in the tropical forest of Cusco, where he has his own house. Honorato remembers that it has been a long time since he has had nothing to offer his family but the knowledge of pineapple sowing and harvesting techniques, and since then he started to produce and sell this product. Today he sells his product to large wholesalers at a competitive price, and with the savings from this he was able to acquire a three-wheeled car. With it, he now offers a taxi service, and through this he has been able to earn extra income. His current goal is to diversify his market, so his oldest son is in charge of pineapple cultivation, keeping them safe from the plagues and pests that affect production. The pineapples are ultimately brought to collection centres in their area. Honorato thanks his family for the support and help that they give him in the most difficult moments, and for this reason he wants to open a clothing sales store, with the aim of expanding his market and improving his family's quality of life. This is his sixth loan with MFP, and he is committed to continuing to fulfill his repayment obligations. Furthermore, he thanks the institution for the responsibility. With the requested loan, he will invest in buying pineapple seeds with the need to improve his production, and he also wants to properly maintain his vehicle.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pineapple seeds

loans.name: Shalom Group

texts.es:
Ellos son Shalom (que significa paz o bienestar) un grupo conformado por 11 integrantes los cuales son personas con sueños y deseos de superarse para salir adelante. Todos radican el la Colonia San Miguel Xico 4ª sección Valle de Chalco, Estado de México. Este grupo se formo gracias a que escucharon de fundación por parte de una conocida y se decidieron por pedir informes.

Guadalupe F. M. integrante del grupo Shalom. Tiene 40 años solamente término de estudiar la secundaria, es madre soltera, con dos hijos una de 20 y 2 años. Guadalupe se dedica a la venta de artículos escolares en una papelería desde hace seis años ya que desea darle un mejor futuro a su familia, le gustan las ventas y se le facilita la atención hacia la gente, para ella es muy satisfactorio decir que tiene su propio negocio, diariamente abre desde temprano y cierra ya por la tarde, hay días en los cuales las ventas no van bien pero aun así trata de salir adelante.             

Con este crédito quiere comprar más artículos como: libretas, colores, juegos geométricos, gomas, sacapuntas, lápices, para poder tener mas surtida la papelería. Los planes que ella tiene son: poder terminar de arreglar su casa y seguir dándoles estudio a sus hijos, llegar a tener su propio local y no seguir pagando renta.

Los demás integrantes de este grupo son:  
Aurora R. Hernández (Venta de zapatos y colchas por catalogo)                           
Javier P. C. (Venta de materiales para construcción)
Patricia C. C. (Venta de Colchas y Edredones por catalogo)                        
Sixto J. C. (Venta de articulos de temporada, bisuteria)    
Laura O. Páramo (Venta de Avon y Jafra)       
Mariana R. López (Venta de zapatos por catalogo)
David Ramírez M.  (Venta de discos y galletas)
Abigail Sánchez C.  (Venta de antojitos y tamales)
Josefina E. Ramírez (Venta de perfumes)
Silvina C. M.  (Venta por catalogo)

Ellos agradecen a Kiva el apoyo que se les brinda para poder tener un mejor futuro y cumplir sus metas.
texts.en:
They are Shalom (which means peace and well-being), a group made up of 11 members, all of whom are persons with dreams and desires to improve and succeed. They all live in the Valle de Chalco area of Colonia San Miguel, Mexico. This group was formed thanks to a mutual acquaintance who told them about FRAC, which they then decided to inquire about. Guadalupe, a member of the group Shalom, is 40 years old. She just finished high school and is a single mother with two children, 20 years old and 2 years old. Guadalupe has sold school supplies in a stationery shop for the past 6 years as she desires a better future for her family. She likes sales; it helps her attend to people. For her, it is very rewarding to have her own business. Everyday she opens early and closes late. There are days when the sales are not good, but even then she tries to come out ahead. With this loan she wants to buy more articles, such as notebooks, coloring instruments, geometric games, erasers, pencil sharpeners and pencils, to have more merchandise at the stationery shop. Her plans are to finish fixing her house, giving her children an education and to have her own place so she no longer has to pay rent. The other members of the group are: Aurora (Sale of shoes and bedspreads by catalog) Javier (Sale of construction materials) Patricia (Sale of bedspreads and comforters by catalog) Sixto (Sale of seasonal articles, imitation jewelry and other trinkets) Patricia (Sale of bedspreads and comforters by catalog) Laura (Sale of Avon and Jafra) Mariana (Sale of shoes by catalog) David (Sale of CDs and buscuits) Abigail (Sale of snacks and tamales) Josefina (Sale of perfumes) Silvina (Sale by catalog) They are grateful for the support Kiva has given them to have a better future and accomplish their goals.

Translated from Spanish by Tania Mazumdar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of catalogs, shoes, bedspreads and comforters, perfumery, lotions, biscuits, CDs.

location.town: Valle De Chalco Solidaridad  Estado De Mexico

loans.name: Chantale

texts.en: Chantale is a single mother, age 42. She has 6 children between the ages 4 and 24. She is sending 5 children to school with her small income that comes from selling salted fish at the fish market. With the loan, she would like to purchase better quality fish for her business and increase her stock as well. She has been selling fish since 1992, starting with just 50,000 CFA (about $100). She has a reputation in her community that she's like a business "man" because she's very strong and exact with her business deals.

loans.use: Purchasing better quality fish for sale

loans.name: G.s. Lucia Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Lucia Teofilia y Cristina son personas muy luchadoras y admirables. Pues el deseo de salir adelante con sus negocios y familias les da el motivo cada día para esforzarse aun mas. Ambas se dedican a la venta de mariscos por lo que anteriormente vendían de manera ambulante  y tomaban diferentes rutas, en la actualidad ambas han sabido manejar muy bien sus negocios y tienen un tramo en el mercado en donde tienen una variedad de clientes, ellas conversan con sus clientes y le ofrecen lo mejor para que siempre recurran a su negocio.
